column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87235,2019,"Globalization, Digitalization and Culture",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['prof.dr. P Arora', 'V Balan, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The so-called Islamic State recruits members from around the world for their cause through Twitter. Netflix recently declared that after analysing their browsing statistics, they realized that the old constructs of cultural taste in association with the usual suspects of gender, class and age are irrelevant in their algorithmic design. Solidarity marches are happening more frequently around the world –the Occupy movement, Women’s march, and March for Science. What these diverse phenomena are pointing out today is that we live in an increasingly global world where through social media, we are able to create new forms of communities, cultures and contexts that go beyond national borders.

Hence, it is worth asking: Is the notion of the nation state redundant? Does culture matter today in the age of the internet? As social networking sites and their impact spans across borders, are we living in a post-cultural age? To talk of global and representative practice, we need to expand our frames of reference, revisit sacred discourses and Western-biased rubrics of digital design and practice. A paradigm shift is needed in approaching cultural phenomena on the internet with a more global-oriented, open- ended and pluralistic perspective. This seminar investigates popular events, claims and trends by going into the history of dominant theories of influence over these decades including (post) structuralism, (post) modernism, (post) Marxism, feminism and (post)colonial discourse .This opens up critical discussions on key topics such as privacy/surveillance, labour/leisure, activism, democracy, and media consumption/production.  This is essential for students to be able to position their research and target audience within a more globally architected digital and cultural landscape.

column1: <body>Het goederenrecht vormt samen met het verbintenissenrecht een van de twee pijlers van het vermogensrecht. Iedereen heeft te maken met goederenrecht, of het nu de vraag betreft wie eigendom van een gestolen fiets heeft of de vraag aan welke eisen een bank moet voldoen wil zij bewerkstelligen dat zij een geldig pandrecht krijgt op de handelsvorderingen van haar debiteur. Het goederenrecht is daarnaast onlosmakelijk verbonden met het insolventierecht. Denk aan vragen als, moet de curator van de dief van bovengenoemde gestolen fiets deze fiets ook in faillissement teruggeven, of moet de fiets juist ten behoeve van de gezamenlijke schuldeisers worden verkocht? En mag de bank, die een geldig pandrecht op de handelsvorderingen van haar debiteur heeft verkregen, haar vordering in faillissement verrekenen? Dat en meer komt aan bod tijdens het vak goederen- en insolventierecht.</body>

column1: <body>In dit vak komt zowel het goederenrecht als het insolventierecht aan de orde. Bij het B1-vak Inleiding privaatrecht is de basis van het goederenrecht in hoofdlijnen behandeld. In dit vak wordt dieper op het goederenrecht ingegaan en staan verhaal, zekerheid en insolventie centraal. Het vak heeft daarbij tot doel de studenten de hoofdregels van het goederen- en insolventierecht bij te brengen, zodat zij in de (commerciële) praktijk zelfstandig een goederen- of insolventierechtelijke casus kunnen oplossen. Vanwege het grote belang van dit leerstuk in de praktijk wordt extra diep ingegaan op het leerstuk van de verpanding van vorderingen.</body>

column3: In the governance lab students will be confronted  with real life governance problems and will be challenged to apply their theoretical knowledge of the courses in analyzing these problems but also be challenged to develop practical solutions for the problems they are working on. Practitioners presenting the governance problems to students will provide feedback on the given solutions. As such the governance lab sessions will provide the practical testing ground for developing analytical and managerial skills of the students.

column2: </body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: After the governance lab sessions students are able to:
• recognize and analyze practical governance problems;
column5: assist practitioners with their analysis of governance problems and develop practical solutions for these problems;

column3:
• organize processes of joint decision-making and problem solving;
  • reflect on the problems they analyse and the solutions they porovide as well as on the processes that take place to organize these.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: This module introduces the students to ‘law and governance’ by focusing on a field that combines both perspectives: regulatory governance. ‘Regulation’, which is not necessarily a synonym for ‘rulemaking’, is central to governing society. The regulatory approach to law and governance recognizes that law cannot solve all societal problems but also that law brings important safeguards to the table. The governance perspective points to the importance of solid institutional design and culture. Why do we regulate and what do we know about different regulatory approaches, including self-regulation? In what ways do international organisations and NGOs try to influence domestic regulatory governance? The course also deals with the possibilities and limitations of regulatory impact analysis and participation as central governance tools.

The module takes a practical approach, using group work on case studies as a way of gaining experience with the application of tools and concepts of regulatory governance in the context of public administration and law making.

column2: </body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: At the end of this module the students will have:

column5: Understood the basic tools and concepts of governance and regulatory governance in particular.
Thought about how to apply these in the practical context of public administration and lawmaking.
Appreciated the roles and functions of different governance tools, such as indicators in international and national lawmaking processes.
Considered various regulatory governance strategies and have acquired experience with choosing a strategy in a particular situation.

column2: </body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89348,2019,Governance and Strategy,Engels, Nederlands",Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,"['dr. J Weenink', 'J Kostenzer', 'MJ Stevens, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Healthcare managers increasingly are confronted with changes in the policy environment affecting the ways they organize and manage daily care processes. For example, legal requirements for patient participation force healthcare managers to install patient representatives in their advisory boards, and safety regulations ask for structured ways of organizing and accounting for the quality of care within healthcare organizations. Policy measures also influence the strategic choices of managers; if patient safety is displayed as an important problem in healthcare, rendering patient safety a top priority of the healthcare institution can be a valuable way of presenting the institution to third-party payers and patients.

Yet, incorporating national policy aims and measures in the organization’s policies also transforms the role of the healthcare organization. A healthcare organization is not a neutral adaptor of national policy requirements, but actively gives shape to these policies. For instance, what patient participation means and how the actual role of patients in the healthcare organization’s decision making process is fleshed out in practice, gets shape in the day-to-day interactions between health care managers, healthcare practitioners and quality staff.
This course aims to provide HCM students with theoretical lenses as well as practical knowledge to the understanding and dealing with governance and strategy issues in healthcare organizations.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
• Students are able to explain theories on governance and strategy.
• Students are able to analyse governance issues in healthcare from different theoretical perspectives on governance.
• Students are able to analyse strategic issues in healthcare from different theoretical perspectives on strategy.
• Students are able to evaluate contemporary challenges and changes in healthcare governance and strategy;
• Students are able to deal with, and reflect on, complex healthcare issues in a serious game.

column1: Het vak Governance in de zorg focust zich op de drie partijen in de zorg, de zorgaanbieder, de zorgverzekeraar en de patiënten(vereniging). Vanuit het rechtspersonenrecht wordt deze drie partijen nader belicht. Daarnaast maakt de student in het vak Governance in de zorg kennis met de zeer uiteenlopende relaties waarmee mensen aan deze zorgorganisaties verbonden (kunnen) zijn, variërend van hoogopgeleide, vrijgevestigde medisch specialisten tot uitzendkrachten werkzaam in de schoonmaak, van bestuurders, interne toezichtzichthouders tot leden van cliëntenraden en ondernemingsraden. Aandacht wordt besteed aan onder meer vraagstukken van governance, medezeggenschap en arbeidsrecht.

• De student spreidt een kritische en analytische houding ten toon tijdens de colleges, bij het schrijven van de paper en het houden van de presentatie.
• De student durft een eigen mening te uiten tijdens colleges, door middel van het doen van onderbouwde uitspraken met betrekking tot de behandelde stof.

column1: Governance of information systems, enterprises, and supply chains studies the design of incentives (contracts, ownership structures, …) and coordination mechanisms to channel business activities in value-creating ways.
Session 9: Limited cognition and governance structure

The lectures present the core ideas as simple as possible. This is done in a two-tier approach. First, the main topics are introduced at a master-level. Second, some of the classic articles in the field will be studied in more detail, depending on the level of the students participating in the course.
Exercises are assigned to prepare you for the upcoming lecture.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85569,2019,Governance of Migration and Diversity,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. A Pisarevskaya', 'dr. AS Leerkes', 'dr. FG Snel', 'prof.dr. PWA Scholten']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course provides a broader theoretical background on issues of governance in migration and diversity, integrating the various disciplinary perspectives of the GMD master programme (history, sociology, public administration, urban studies, international relations and development) and connects these to topical and hands-on governance questions of migration and diversity.

The course consists of preparatory sessions focusing on the theoretical background of the respective governance issues and site-visits to organizations involved in the topic. The subject for the seminars and site-visits vary depending on what is topical at the time, but can include topics like discrimination, radicalisation, segregation, high-skilled migration, refugee migration, migration corridors, transnational communities and political representations of migrants. During the seminars and site-visits the students engage in discussion with both scholars and practitioners on the topic.
Finally the students will apply their interdisciplinary knowledge on governance of migration and diversity in a critical review of governance issue of choice.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Understand how theoretical perspectives of the master programme can be integrated and applied around topical issues of migration and diversity governance
• Apply the literature from the master programme to concrete governance challenges in migration and diversity
• Critically assess a governance issue from different disciplinary perspectives

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89941,2019,Governing Healthy Cities,Engels,Erasmus University College,,['dr. G Noordzij'],,Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: How to create and govern healthy cities? This question is at the forefront of the minds of local city administrators as well as international organisations like the World Health Organisation (WHO). Increasingly, people live in large cities where they are exposed to all kinds of health risks (e.g. air pollution) and challenges (e.g. rising health inequalities). The governance of these risks and challenges is one of the key responsibilities that local policy makers and health professionals are facing around the globe.

The governing ideal of ‘the healthy city’ represents a fundamental shift in how we view health: from individual biophysical models of health towards holistic notions of health that presuppose interconnectedness of place, health and well-being of communities. This conceptual shift becomes visible in new discourses on ‘positive health’ and ‘social resilience’ that we will unravel and apply during this course. These new discourses are not just words/visions, they also inspire policymakers and professionals to adopt new experimental approaches to organise healthy cities: such as cross-sector collaboration (i.e. joining up health, welfare, work, education), community ‘greening’ initiatives and urban labs that promote resilience in neighbourhoods.

The aim of Governing Healthy Cities is to prepare students to be engaged world citizens who can play an active role in the development of academic knowledge for society. This active role will be embedded in this course by giving students the opportunity to write a policy report for a societal partner that is involved in governing healthy cities. The policy report addresses a key challenge/problem of the societal partner. By making a convincing analysis of this challenge and by formulating practically relevant recommendations, students can actively contribute to society. Apart from the policy report, grading for the course will be based on an open-questions exam.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The main objective of this course is for students to get acquainted with healthcare governance as a concept and the different shapes and forms of governance in practice. More specifically, the following learning goals apply to this course:

column2: • Students have an understanding of the shift from government to governance
• Students have an understanding of different coordination modes in governance (market, state, networks and communities)
• Students can explain the connection between place and healthcare governance.
• Students can apply theoretical concepts from the literature to analyze empirical cases of healthcare governance (see the 2 cases in Feijenoord, Rotterdam)
• Students will be able to develop useful policy recommendations for Feijenoord on the basis of the key concepts and themes of this course
• Students are able to explain and critically reflect on how people can be ‘responsibilized’ and be ‘made governable’
• Students are able to effectively discuss literature and issues on governance during meetings
• Students are able to provide peer-support to each other during workgroups by reading and discussing each other’s draft version of the report
• Students are able to write a coherent essay on the basis of a clear research question.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/88768,2019,Governing Healthy Cities,Engels,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['DV Ivanova, PhD', 'MJ Stevens, MSc', 'S Huizenga - Rahmawan, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Cities are increasingly seen as important places to ‘govern’ health.  In the Netherlands, cities have gained more responsibilities since the decentralizations of care and support to local municipalities. On the local level, solutions needs to be found for pressing problems, such as rising health inequalities between neighbourhoods, fragmented public service provision, and unsuitable housing for aging populations. To address these problems in innovative ways, experiments are being conducted in urban labs and inter-sectoral networks are set-up to enhance collaboration between different stakeholders in the city.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The aim of this course is to provide students with theoretical and practical knowledge about governance of healthy cities as well as skills to perform ‘action research’ in the city of Rotterdam on the basis of which they will write a policy report. By following this course, students will develop an in-depth understanding of the possibilities and difficulties of governing healthy cities.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86701,2019,Governing Social Inequalities: The role of welfare states and labour market characteristics,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. A Gugushvili', 'dr. BE French', 'dr. G Mari']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Structural inequalities and social, economic and demographic developments affect the social risks that citizens face. Those consequences are moderated by institutions of the welfare state and the labor market, which adapt their arrangements in response to these developments. However, while institutions mitigate social inequalities (i.e. reducing the income gap between the rich and poor through redistributive policies), they simultaneously produce new social inequalities (often as unintended consequences).

In this course we will focus on the complex interplay between social consequences of recent social, economic and demographic developments and institutions of the welfare state and the labor market. We will focus on both old and new social inequalities (e.g., those that occur in post-industrial societies) and will discuss, among others, developments in old age provisions, social support, balancing work and family life, and health care. In this course, students investigate the role that organizations, labor markets and welfare states have in maintaining, strengthening or weakening social inequalities. In doing so, we will take a comparative perspective and focus on developments in different European countries.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Identify sociological theories concerning welfare states and labour market conditions;
• Reflect on how institutions of the welfare state and the labour market are affected by economic, social and political developments;

• Illustrate how the institutions of welfare states and the labour market mitigate ‘old’ social inequalities while simultaneously producing and intensifying new ones (often as unintended consequences)
• Apply sociological theoretical framework to analyse social policies and their social consequences;

column1: After successful completion of this course, students will also be able to:

column2: • Critically assess empirical evidence and propose/evaluate possible research designs for a given question;
• Report findings in a clear and effective manner (in writing).

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87585,2019,Governing Urban Economic Growth and Innovation,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. J Fransen', 'prof.dr. FG van Oort']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Cities are dynamic engines of economies growth and innovation, but they also create negative externalities such as inequality, poverty and pollution. Urban economies are primarily coordinated by market transactions, many of which take place at an (inter)national level. The ability of urban governments to influence markets is limited and widely discussed. The course adopts a network governance perspective, debating if and how varying combinations of markets, state and non-state actors steer and facilitate local economic development. The question is if and how urban network governance can stimulate economic growth and innovation, while overcoming negative externalities.

The course first discusses multi-disciplinary factors driving economic growth, creativity, innovation and entrepreneurship in a global economy. Subsequently the section zooms in on transitions towards sustainable and resilient urban economies, responding to recent challenges such as climate change, financial crises, growing inequality and the Brexit.

column2: <title></title>

column1: <body>By the end of the course, students are able to:

column2: • Distinguish and apply different perspectives to urban economic governance
• Analyze the complex nature of urban economic governance across and within sectors and cities
• Formulate conditions for sustainable and inclusive urban economic growth and inclusive innovation
• Determinate strategies to overcome negative externalities (like poverty, inequality and pollution)

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Handelingen en gedragingen als misdaad kwalificeren en bestraffen, is geen theorieloze en eeuwig onveranderlijke praktijk. Aan dit gebeuren liggen talrijke filosofische en politieke vooronderstellingen ten grondslag die evolueren in de tijd. Over deze theoretische vooronderstellingen en achterliggende historische denkkaders, wordt in het vak grondslagen van de criminologie gereflecteerd.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Inzicht verschaffen in de maatschappelijke verhoudingen en filosofische opvattingen die een rol hebben gespeeld bij de historische ontwikkeling van de ideeën over misdaad en straf.
• Inzicht verschaffen in de vraag waarom in bepaalde historische periodes gewetensdelicten zoals ketterij strafwaardig geacht werden en hoe men reageerde op een verdenking van hekserij.
• Inzicht verschaffen in de rol die de godsdienst speelde in de vervolging van gewetensdelicten en hekserij.

• Studenten kritisch laten nadenken over de vraag waarom een staat het recht heeft om diegenen die afwijken van bepaalde normen te straffen en inzicht verschaffen in de wijze waarop dit filosofisch gerechtvaardigd wordt?
• Studenten kritisch leren reflecteren over de reikwijdte van overheidsmacht en over de filosofische oorsprong en de grondslag van individuele rechten tegenover de staat.
• Inzicht verschaffen in de rol en de betekenis van de Verlichtingsfilosofie in dit proces.
• Studenten kennis laten maken met het debat tussen utilisten en retributivisten in de strafrechtsfilosofie.
• Studenten kritisch laten nadenken over de vraag of (en zo ja hoe) foltering en de doodstraf kunnen gerechtvaardigd worden (en indien niet, waarom?)
• Inzicht verschaffen in de verschillende ethische theorieën die een antwoord formuleren op de vraag wanneer de overheid iets strafrechtelijk mag verbieden?
• Studenten kritisch doen nadenken over de vraag of alleen individuen misdaden kunnen plegen dan wel of ook staten en (internationale) organisaties dat doen?
• Studenten doen reflecteren over de vraag of het object van de criminologie ruimer is dan louter datgene wat door de strafwetgever strafbaar is gesteld.
• Studenten kennis laten maken met de manier waarop de criminologie als wetenschap is ontstaan en hoe zij zich verhoudt tot de (totalitaire) politiek.
• Studenten kennis laten maken met het debat over vrije wil en determinisme in de strafrechtstheorie.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85669,2019,Groups at Work,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. H van Mierlo'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

It is no coincidence that our psychology curriculum in Rotterdam begins with a course about people in groups (social psychology). Groups were central to the human past, are central to our present, and will continue to be central to the human future. To understand human behavior, we need to understand groups, because people live in groups, play in groups, and.... work and perform in groups.

As a Work and Organizational Psychologist, you will be faced with groups at work all the time: departments, project teams, discussion groups, boards, work teams, et cetera. Often, your involvement with groups will be about improving them, about suggesting or implementing changes to make groups or teams more effective. In your future job you may, for example, train groups, build groups (or teams), advise groups, design groups, disband groups, address groups, motivate groups, study groups, or simply participate in groups.

By presenting state-of-the-art knowledge about various aspects of groups at work, this course will give you the opportunity to prepare for these and other intriguing encounters with the practice of group work.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>‘Groups at Work’ is a specialized Master course that will introduce you to different aspects of groups at work. The tutorial group meetings and lectures enable you to become familiar with the state of affairs in group research and encourage you to further develop an academic attitude: a constructive, critical attitude towards the things you see, hear, and read. At the end of this course:

column2: • You have knowledge and understanding of the basics of groups at work, diversity in groups, group processes and emergent states, and group leadership.
• You have developed a critical view of the literature about these topics

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

HONOURS PROGRAMME - What is sustainability? Why should it matter to you? Answering these questions will generate more questions. In this course, the concept of sustainability will be presented and discussed from several perspectives.  Students will gain insights into the triple bottom line approach to sustainability and examine the different aspects and challenges it encompasses for contemporary societies and individuals. This approach allows students to explore three aspects of sustainability: social, environmental and economic dimensions.

Throughout this course, students will not only acquire both a theoretical and practical understanding of sustainability, but also develop a variety of skills to conduct empirical research on this topic. Students will have the opportunity to collaborate with participants from China to collect first-hand data. Students’ own research projects will allow them to investigate sustainability practices in China. This course is designed for students to engage with the intercultural dimension of sustainability and work in small diverse groups on their research project.</body>

column1: Human Resources have increasingly been recognised as a source of competitive advantage and as such good people management is vital for organisations. The course is designed to develop a thorough knowledge and understanding of the effective management of people. After exploring the theoretical origins of HRM, the emergence of HR strategy and the relationship between business strategy and HRM strategy, the course will focus on discussing and analysing important HRM activities such as HR planning, job analysis and job design, recruitment and selection, and performance management.   A deepened understanding of the strategic character of these practical HRM activities provides students with the knowledge and skills required for the integration of HR policies into a coherent HRM strategy, which implementation will contribute to a high-performance organisation.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89082,2019,HRM Master Thesis,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. MS Kaandorp'],,

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: De module biedt een inleiding in de centrale theorieën in de wetenschappelijke literatuur over Human Resource Management (HRM), leiderschap en prestaties. Conform de ontwikkeling van dit vakgebied, waarbij vooral de strategische betekenis van de personele factor wordt benadrukt, wordt ook aandacht geschonken aan de context waarin HRM tot stand komt. Daarnaast wordt aandacht gegeven aan de toepassing van HRM in de publieke sector in vergelijking met de private sector. Publieke en private organisaties verschillen onder meer in de omgevingscondities waar zij mee te maken hebben welke van invloed zijn op de organisatie en HRM strategie.

Een centrale veronderstelling binnen de HRM literatuur is dat de relatie tussen HRM en prestaties verloopt via de beleving en het gedrag van werknemers, zoals tevredenheid en betrokkenheid. Daarbij wordt er een onderscheid gemaakt tussen HRM zoals beschreven in het beleid en de perceptie die de werknemers van HRM hebben, welke veelal wordt beïnvloed door leiderschap. Er zal daarom in het bijzonder ook worden beschreven welke rol de leidinggevende heeft in relatie tot HRM.

De module bouwt voort op het vak Organisatie & Management in Bachelor 1. Daarnaast wordt voortgebouwd op de M&T leerlijn in het curriculum, waarbij vooral wordt ingegaan op het ontwerp van (kwantitatief en kwalitatief) onderzoek en de bijbehorende analyses. In de werkgroepen worden de aangereikte theorieën en modellen toegepast en onderzoeksvaardigheden verder uitgebouwd.

• het strategisch HRM-beleid m.b.t. een onderwerp naar keuze analyseren in een publieke organisatie, en daarover rapporteren volgens de wetenschappelijke richtlijnen.

column1: Macro principles of good writing and publishing (Day 1)
1.    What makes a paper a good paper; why do some paper get published and others not
3.    Writing as a contribution to scholarly discourse: Finding your conversation, finding a story to tell
4.    Structuring a paper: Different options and when they are appropriate.
6.    Knowing the key ingredients for each section of a paper: what has go into an introduction, a literature review, etc., and where exactly should it be located.
7.    Good sections, good paragraphing (pyramid principle, topic sentences etc.)
8.    Rules for building strong sentences, cohesion among sentences (e.g., relating to action characters, strong verbs, 2-3-1, pargraphing, creating overlap, from known to unknown, concision)
9.    Choice of tense and mode to fit section of the paper and the content, choice of words that send the right “signals”, etc.
10.    Conducting your writing project: Strategies for productive writing and editing
11.    Writing to get published in leading academic journals
14.    Measuring and managing your impact as a scholar

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: This course aims at improving participants’ academic writing skills, and help them to publish papers at leading journals. The course is an intensive one-week course, where participants are expected to focus exclusively on this course. Participants are expected to submit a piece of writing before the start of the seminar. This can be a draft of a conference paper or a draft of a regular paper. During the course, you will be invited to revise the written piece after each day. At the end of the course, the initially submitted piece of writing should be revised substantially and should be re-submitted to the professor. Participants should also actively take part in the discussions

column2: • At the end of this course, participants know how to craft high quality papers.
• Participants know the principles of good academic writing, and recognize these principles.
• Participants improve their own writing and editing.
• Participants understand the publishing process, including research ethics issues that can arise in its course.
• Participants understand how scholarly impact is created and measured, and can apply this knowledge to increase their own impact.
• Participants get an understanding why many papers get rejected.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>De economie draait op het kopen en verkopen van de meest diverse goederen en diensten. Allereerst wordt daarom aandacht besteed aan het (internationale) kooprecht. Wat zijn de rechten en verplichtingen van koper en verkoper? In handelstransacties zijn koper en verkoper meestal niet op dezelfde plaats gevestigd. De verkochte goederen zullen dus vervoerd moeten worden. Wat indien de goederen tijdens dit transport beschadigd worden? Het vervoerrecht regelt de rechten en verplichtingen van de partijen die bij het vervoer betrokken zijn. De gekochte goederen moeten uiteraard ook betaald worden. Wanneer koper en verkoper zich niet op dezelfde plaats bevinden wordt het uitvoeren van een betaling minder evident, zeker wanneer koper en verkoper elkaar niet per se vertrouwen. De handelspraktijk heeft hiervoor verschillende oplossingen uitgewerkt, die in belangrijke mate berusten op het concept van waardepapieren. In het onderdeel betalingstechnieken en waardepapieren wordt hieraan aandacht besteed. Wanneer in een transactie iets mis loopt, is het zeer wel denkbaar dat de schadelijder een aansprakelijksvordering heeft op een andere partij. Het instellen van een vorderingen kosten echter tijd en geld, en draagt steeds een procesrisico in zich. Vaak zullen de partijen bij een handelstransactie risico's dan ook verzekeren, zodat zij zich bij een schadegeval tot hun verzekeraar kunnen wenden i.p.v. de uitkomst van een procedure te moeten afwachten. Het verzekeringsrecht regelt de rechten en plichten van partijen in het kader van een verzekeringsovereenkomst. Tenslotte wordt aandacht besteed aan twee rechtsdomeinen die niet noodzakelijk, maar wel vaak een rol spelen bij handelstransacties. Vooreerst het recht inzake handelstussenpersonen. Producenten willen hun producten vaak ook wel in het buitenland aanbieden, maar vinden het moeilijk om dit vanop afstand te doen, en maken daarom gebruik van plaatselijke tussenpersonen (distributeurs, handelsagenten, enz.). De opdrachtgever en de tussenpersoon hebben soms echter uiteenlopende of zelfs tegenstrijdige belangen, wat in de praktijk regelmatig tot problemen aanleiding geeft. Het handelstussenpersonenrecht regelt deze materie. Tenslotte wordt aandacht besteed aan het intellectuele eigendomsrecht. Producenten investeren tijd en geld in de ontwikkeling van producten, en worden door het intellectuele eigendomsrecht beschermd tegen ongeoorloofd kopiëren en namaak.</body>

column1: <body>Het doel van dit vak is om de student een basiskennis te verschaffen van de diverse onderdelen van het handelsrecht, met name het (internationale) kooprecht, het vervoerrecht, het (internationale) betalings- en waardepapierenrecht, het verzekeringsrecht, het handelstussenpersonenrecht, en het intellectuele eigendomsrecht.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/88286,2019,Handelsrecht,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. FL Stevens', 'mr. M de Vries', 'prof.mr. FGM Smeele', 'prof.mr. N van Tiggele - van der Velde', 'prof.mr.dr. T Cohen Jehoram', 'SCLM Bos, LLM']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>De economie draait op het kopen en verkopen van de meest diverse goederen en diensten. Allereerst wordt daarom aandacht besteed aan het (internationale) kooprecht. Wat zijn de rechten en verplichtingen van koper en verkoper? In handelstransacties zijn koper en verkoper meestal niet op dezelfde plaats gevestigd. De verkochte goederen zullen dus vervoerd moeten worden. Wat indien de goederen tijdens dit transport beschadigd worden? Het vervoerrecht regelt de rechten en verplichtingen van de partijen die bij het vervoer betrokken zijn. De gekochte goederen moeten uiteraard ook betaald worden. Wanneer koper en verkoper zich niet op dezelfde plaats bevinden wordt het uitvoeren van een betaling minder evident, zeker wanneer koper en verkoper elkaar niet per se vertrouwen. De handelspraktijk heeft hiervoor verschillende oplossingen uitgewerkt, die in belangrijke mate berusten op het concept van waardepapieren. In het onderdeel betalingstechnieken en waardepapieren wordt hieraan aandacht besteed. Wanneer in een transactie iets mis loopt, is het zeer wel denkbaar dat de schadelijder een aansprakelijksvordering heeft op een andere partij. Het instellen van een vorderingen kosten echter tijd en geld, en draagt steeds een procesrisico in zich. Vaak zullen de partijen bij een handelstransactie risico's dan ook verzekeren, zodat zij zich bij een schadegeval tot hun verzekeraar kunnen wenden i.p.v. de uitkomst van een procedure te moeten afwachten. Het verzekeringsrecht regelt de rechten en plichten van partijen in het kader van een verzekeringsovereenkomst. Tenslotte wordt aandacht besteed aan twee rechtsdomeinen die niet noodzakelijk, maar wel vaak een rol spelen bij handelstransacties. Vooreerst het recht inzake handelstussenpersonen. Producenten willen hun producten vaak ook wel in het buitenland aanbieden, maar vinden het moeilijk om dit vanop afstand te doen, en maken daarom gebruik van plaatselijke tussenpersonen (distributeurs, handelsagenten, enz.). De opdrachtgever en de tussenpersoon hebben soms echter uiteenlopende of zelfs tegenstrijdige belangen, wat in de praktijk regelmatig tot problemen aanleiding geeft. Het handelstussenpersonenrecht regelt deze materie. Tenslotte wordt aandacht besteed aan het intellectuele eigendomsrecht. Producenten investeren tijd en geld in de ontwikkeling van producten, en worden door het intellectuele eigendomsrecht beschermd tegen ongeoorloofd kopiëren en namaak.</body>

column1: The Syrian civil war, the Ebola epidemic, hurricane Katrina, the Rohingya crisis, the earthquakes in Nepal and Haiti, the Japanese tsunami, the Indian Ocean tsunami, the HIV/AIDS epidemic,… the world has experienced many large humanitarian crises in past decades. Climate change, population growth, and rapid urbanization will likely only increase their frequency and impact in the future. At the same time, the world is still facing several substantial development challenges. For example, nearly 2 billion people still lack access to basic medicines and more than half the world population still lacks access to essential health services.

These health and humanitarian crises come with extreme demands for logistics, technology, and operations management. Extreme in terms of operating conditions. Extreme due to the scarcity of resources. And extreme in terms of consequences for health and well-being. For example, managing disaster response is like organizing the next Olympic Games without knowing where it will take place, when it will take place, and how many people will come. Though this seems pretty impossible, the way response is being prepared and managed is a matter of life and death for many. Similarly, increasing access to medicines and health services in low and middle income countries is about addressing a disproportionally heavy burden of disease with very limited resources (doctors, clinics, outreach/vaccination teams, transportation, infrastructures, money…). Maximizing the effectiveness of available resources is hence key, which is exactly what logistics, technology, and operations management is about.

This course provides an introduction to the important field of Health & Humanitarian Logistics and corresponding UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Though it covers some theory, the main focus will be on learning by doing. In case studies, a simulation game, and individual and group exercises, you will work on real and complex challenges related to disaster relief, medicine supply chains, and health service delivery in low and middle income countries. Examples include: Where should one locate warehouses to pre-position relief goods? What/how much to stock there? What logistics network should one set up to handle incoming relief goods after a disaster? How to optimize the dispatching of these goods? What technology is useful to support relief activities? Should governments adopt a push or a pull system for medicine supplies to health facilities? Should drones be used to perform medicine deliveries? In what contexts should one use mobile (i.e., travelling) healthcare providers instead of traditional health facilities? How to screen for epidemic outbreaks?

Given the increasing need for smart use of data in this sector, much emphasis will be put on analyzing datasets and using these to support decisions/ generate insights. While doing so, you will be asked to use the knowledge, methods, and models you have acquainted yourself with during your studies. If you have a background in logistics and supply chain management, you are encouraged to use data analysis and optimization techniques and mathematical models (e.g., for network design, planning, routing, and inventory control). If you are not familiar with these methods and models, you are encouraged to address the challenge using your intuition and methods and models you are familiar with. All students will be challenged to critically assess applicability of such methods and models (which have typically been developed to address business challenges) to the challenge considered. What are the hidden assumptions? What pieces can be transferred? What pieces need to be adjusted?
In parallel, the course will cover some basic concepts, background knowledge, and theory about Health & Humanitarian Logistics, including:

column2: • The goals the health & humanitarian system aims to achieve,
• The stakeholders in the health and humanitarian system,
• How the system works (or is supposed to work),
• The context in which health and humanitarian actors operate,
• The role of logistics in the system, and key logistics challenges,
• New technology (e.g., blockchain, drones) and new business models for addressing these challenges,
• Technology and management approaches for logistics decision making

column1: Though the course will have a major focus on logistics and supply chain management, students from all MSc programs are encouraged to participate. Many challenges in the health & humanitarian system are multi-faceted, and relate to/ benefit from knowledge from various disciplines, including analytics, strategy, finance, innovation, etc.</body>

column1: The main objective of this course is to introduce you to big open problems in the health and humanitarian sector, to critically assess transferability of business school knowledge, models, and methods and to creatively adjust or add to them. Upon completing this course, students can:

column2: • Explain the general goals the health & humanitarian system aims to achieve, the role of different stakeholders in this system, and the big challenges it is facing,
• Identify the role of logistics in addressing these challenges,
• Generate solutions for/ insights on several of these challenges, often in a data-driven manner,
• Assess applicability of related models (e.g., facility location, inventory control, planning, and routing) while addressing these challenges,
• Adjust such models to account for the specifics of the challenge and context considered,
• Discuss the potential of new technologies and business models to address challenges the health & humanitarian system is facing

column1: This course examines the links between health, health expenditure and economic development at the macro and at micro level.
-Health and economic development at the macro level
-The measurement of health and its returns to health
-Impact evaluation methods in the field of health and development
-Public provision of health and its pitfalls
-Recent advances in empirical research of health and development

column1: This course aims to critically examine the inter-linkage between health and economic development at the macro and micro level both theoretically and empirically.
-Introduce concepts of health and its measurement in the field of development economics
-Illustrate the theoretical links between health and economic development
-Discuss theories of health behaviors and investments
-Critically analyze economic and political mechanisms in the field of health service provision
-Introduce theoretical frameworks and empirical tools (including impact evaluation methods) to study the linkage between health and economic development</body>

column1: <body>This course will introduce students to economic analysis of health and health care. The health care sector is a more and more important sector of the economy, with health care expenditures having reached 10% of GDP in most OECD countries. The performance of health care systems still has a lot to benefit from sound economic analysis. We will start by addressing the question of what makes health care a different economic good. The special features of health care mean that the standard economic tools are not sufficient to study its demand and supply. We will learn the main economic models that have been developed to analyse these issues. This course will also provide an introduction to economic evaluation of health care. This area of health economics provides information on which products - health care interventions - should be provided for consumption by patients, by weighing the costs and benefits of various alternatives. In many instances, such information is now required for new technologies to get access to the health care market. Questions that will be addressed include:

column2: • Should governments provide health care?
• Do doctors induce unnecessary demand for their services?
• Can poor people pay for their own health insurance?
• Should health insurance premia depend on how (un)healthy people are?
• Do poor people in developed and developing countries have access to the health care services they need?
• How to determine the value/utility that people attach to health?
• What health care services should be included in the basic insurance package?
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• To become acquainted with the discipline of Health Economics.
• Understand the major theories in this field.
• Understand the main empirical work in this field.
• Know main methods used to help decision makers choose the most efficient treatments.
• To be able to apply basics of methods for economic evaluation of health care.
• To be able to understand and critically assess published studies in health economics.

• The mark of the exam should be at least 5.5.
• If a small number of students fail the examination, the re-examination will be oral, instead of written.

column1: <body>Why do people smoke, refuse vaccination, have unsafe sex, eat unhealthily and are physically inactive despite the health risks? How can we help individuals, communities and societies to live healthier and maintain these behaviours to prevent diseases? In this course, we will explain how health psychology can be used to address behaviours that can affect our health. We will do this by (1) explaining how biological, psychological, and sociocultural factors contribute to physical, mental, and social wellbeing, and by (2) exploring health promotion intervention design in a hands-on manner.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Upon completion of this course, you should be able to:

column2: • Understand the reasons underlying the emergence of health psychology;
• Have a basic understanding of the public health consequences of hypertension, diabetes, and sexually transmitted diseases;
• Understand the determinants of health behaviour and identify effective methods of promoting behaviour change and healthier lifestyles;
• Understand the main health risks and positive health behaviours that are relevant to the population at large;
• Understand the role of health behaviours for determining health outcomes;
• Become familiar with behaviour change theories in public health;
• Identify trends in research about the evidence based clinical behaviour of health care professionals;
• Discuss the role of theories and techniques of behaviour change;
• Learn from the experiences of a GP working in the South of Rotterdam;
• Understand sociocultural differences of health and illness;
• Become familiar with a theoretical framework to understand cultural differences and similarities;
• Apply behaviour change theories to design a pilot intervention focused on hypertension/diabetes/sexual and reproductive health;
• Appreciate the challenges and opportunities associated with running an intervention in the field.

column1: We will focus on the development of health service operations management as a field of research, its relevance to develop and improve health services and on the basic concepts of health service operations management. We will use Operations Management theory and concepts for the operations management of individual units within health service provider organizations (e.g. a ward) and for the operations management of care pathways (e.g. mamma cancer diagnosis and treatment) and care chains (e.g. stroke services).

Furthermore we will discuss the concepts underlying Focused Factory, Lean Management, Six Sigma, Business Process Redesign and Theory of Constraints as these are popular approaches in operations management used in continuous improvement of processes in health services. All topics will be introduced in lectures and put into practice in workgroups. Quantitative analyses (with Excel) will be part of both the working group assignments and the individual assignment. To prepare, test and update your Excel knowledge, a formative test in excel is available on the website (Excel skills).
Language: Only the workgroups are in Dutch

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Health Service Operations Management (HSOM) can be defined as the analysis, design, planning and control of all steps necessary to deliver services to clients in healthcare. We use methods and techniques that originate from manufacturing but have been adapted to service industries and health services.

The aim of the course is to make the students familiar with the basic concepts, methods and techniques of health service operations management and to enable them to apply these concepts to services in healthcare.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89352,2019,Health Services Innovation,Engels, Nederlands",Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,"['dr. B Pluut', 'dr. JWM Weggelaar - Jansen', 'prof.dr. AA de Bont']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course focuses on the question; How can organizations develop and evaluate innovative services in health care. The course provides an introduction to innovation science.  Innovations science is interdisciplinary; it combines knowledge from the field of economics, sociology, change management and organizational sciences. Specific questions we will address in this course are: What is the value of specific innovations? What impact do technologies have on clinical practice? Why do certain innovations emerge while others do not? How can you evaluate an innovation (is it better compared to what, who, whom)?

In this course students are asked to participate in an innovation contest (comparable to the Dutch Health Care innovation Award). The examination of the course represents all elements of innovation and implementation processes. Students are asked to write a proposal, to present this proposal to both health care professionals, managers and board members and to review an innovation proposal

De voertaal in de colleges is Engels. In dit vak zijn er geen klassieke werkgroepen, want er is projectonderwijs. Je expliciet bij de vakcoordinator (weggelaar@eshpm.eur.nl) minimaal 3 weken van te voren melden dat je in een projectgroep wilt met alleen studenten die Nederlands spreken. Het rapport en de individuele opdracht mag in het Nederlands worden opgeleverd. De pitch moet in het Engels, maar in jouw werkgroep zitten EUHeM en HCM studenten, die de Engelse taal vloeiend beheersen (en slechts één of twee studenten hoeven te presenteren).

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Students can design and steer an innovation process.
• Students can write a proposal for a care innovation prize which includes a description of the why, the what, the how and the implementation of the innovation;
• Students can apply management skills, e.g. collaboration in teams, project management, creative thinking, present a pitch, write a compact proposal and visualize ideas.
• Students can evaluate an innovation proposal with set of criteria based upon medical, economic, social, managerial an organization theories about innovations.

• Students can evaluate an innovation proposal with set of criteria based upon medical, economic, social, managerial and organization theories about innovations.

FCW van Krugten, MSc', 'dr. HM Blommestein', 'dr. MA Koopmanschap', 'dr. MJ Al', 'dr. MJ Poleij', 'dr. WF Thielen', 'prof.dr. MPMH Rutten - van Molken']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Although patients demand access to all health care programmes available, the scarcity of resources necessitates that choices have to be made. Given that health is such an important matter and that choices usually have far reaching consequences for individuals, the choices require careful consideration, preferably based on transparent and unbiased data. Health Technology Assessment is a multidisciplinary research area closely related to health economics. HTA research attempts to examine the short- and long-term consequences (e.g. health effects and costs) of new and existing health care programs. This is done in a systematic and consistent way in order to provide evidence for the relative cost-effectiveness of health care programs. Policy makers in health care are increasingly using the results of these studies in making choices on priorities in health care.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: By the end of the course students can:
- describe the structure and the objectives of HTA/economic evaluation studies.
- perform the 6 steps of an economic evaluation study.
- describe and discuss the inclusion, measurement and valuation of future costs, productivity costs, informal care and outcomes beyond the QALY in economic evaluations
- explain advantages and disadvantages of various quality of life instruments and can discuss when and how individual instruments should be used.
- explain the relationship between several economic theories and the differences in operationalization of key concepts in economic evaluation studies.
- perform and interpret cost- and cost-effectiveness calculations including analysis of uncertainty with a decision tree and a Markov disease model and reflect upon the design and quality of studies.
- critically discuss the inclusion of economic evaluations  among other policy ingredients in policy reimbursement decisions of new health care interventions.
- explain the difficulties of transferring outcomes of economic evaluations across jurisdictions.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89358,2019,Healthcare Ethics,Engels, Nederlands",Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,"['dr. CM Dieteren', 'dr. KJ Grit', 'dr. MA Koopmanschap', 'prof.mr.dr. MAJM Buijsen']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Conflicts and dilemmas in healthcare are rarely merely technical problems. They tend to have profound moral dimensions which are often overlooked. Policy-advisors as well as managers need to be sensitive to the moral aspects of conflicts and dilemmas occurring in healthcare. Sensibility for the moral side of problems (in healthcare as well as anywhere else) is not self-evident. It is something which must be acquired. In addition, moral problems are also problems which can be solved. Moral reasoning is something that can be learned.

The course introduces students to moral philosophy. What is morality? What constitutes a moral dilemma? Why be moral? Is there truth in morality? What qualifies an act morally? What constitutes moral character? Following these meta-ethical questions, the course surveys major normative ethical theories (including utilitarianism, rights theory and virtue theory), describes methods of moral justification in healthcare ethics, addresses the problem of moral status and agency (what rights people are due, and when) and examines the moral characteristics of the basic relationships (e.g. professionals-patients and clients) inherent to healthcare.

Drawing from contemporary research, case studies and real-life examples, students will learn how the fundamental moral principles of autonomy, benevolence and justice can be expanded to apply to various conflicts and dilemmas in healthcare, from whether or not to withhold or withdraw life-sustaining treatments, to such diverse issues as the legislation of organ donation (opt-in or opt-out?), euthanasia and fulfilled lives, life style choices, access to collectively financed healthcare and solidarity, and expensive drugs and the worth of human life.

At the end of the course, students will have learned that the reasoning typical of the disciplines constituting health sciences, such as (health) economics and (health) law, are but different ways to approach normative problems in healthcare, that there is a common (ethical) language, and that there is a way to include them all when faced with such problems.

In interactive lectures students will be made familiar with the basics of philosophical ethics, healthcare ethics and moral reasoning. In the seminars the theory will be put to practice. During the course students will apply the same method of moral reasoning to a variety of moral problems in healthcare in ever smaller groups. Finally, the individual student is expected to write an essay, providing a moral question of his or her choice, but approved by the staff, by the best possible answer, in the way taught in the seminars.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • The student acquires knowledge and an understanding of the basics of moral philosophy
• The student acquires knowledge and an understanding of the basics of health care ethics
• The student acquires basic moral reasoning skills
• The student is able to apply basic moral reasoning skills to real-life moral dilemmas in healthcare
• The student engages actively in moral discussions
• The student is able to hold a moral position convincingly, expressed in a well-written essay, based on well-researched arguments and sound logic

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87485,2019,Healthcare Procurement & Value Chain Management,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr.ir. EM van Raaij'],,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: In this course we will focus on the procurement process and on value chain management in the healthcare sector. In many countries, healthcare represents one of the largest sectors of the economy; healthcare spend often amounts to 10% of a country’s GDP. This course builds on the key concepts as taught in the core course Purchasing & Supply Management (BM05SCM). This course expands into areas that are not only relevant in healthcare, but also in other sectors, such as services triads, performance-based contracting, best value procurement, European tendering, cooperative purchasing, and negotiation skills.

In healthcare value chains two types of purchasing can be distinguished: purchasing of healthcare and purchasing for healthcare. In purchasing of healthcare, which is done by for instance healthcare insurers, ‘healthcare’ is the service that is purchased. In purchasing for healthcare a diverse set of goods and services is purchased (e.g. catering, temporary labour and medical equipment).

A significant amount of money is spent in the healthcare industry on a yearly basis, which makes that there is a large potential for the purchasing profession to decrease spend, improve quality and increase innovation as well as efficiency. In this course we connect management theory about purchasing with specific characteristics of the healthcare industry.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: This course brings together students from the institute of Healthcare Policy and Management and Rotterdam School of Management to educate them on procurement in the healthcare sector. The course is a mix of lectures and workshops, some of which will be taught by experienced guest lecturers from organizations such as hospitals and insurance companies. The workshops are sessions with 10-20 students, in which there will be ample opportunity to discuss the concepts in-depth and/or to practice specific skills.
For the schedule please refer to the GW4009MD and GW4009MV schedules.

Students will get to understand the role that purchasing plays within and between healthcare organisations and the different ways in which purchasing can contribute to the overall performance of a healthcare organisation and/or a healthcare system. Upon completing this course, students:

column2: •     Can explain the importance of professional purchasing and supply management in healthcare systems;
•     Understand the role that incentives play in buyer-supplier relationships;
•     Understand the importance of supplier relationship management and know the advantages and disadvantages of different types of supplier relationships;
•     Understand the importance of alignment between purchasing and medical professionals and how to achieve such alignment;
•     Can describe the advantages of horizontal buyer-supplier collaboration and the different types of buyer-supplier relationships;
•     Understand the principles of the EU regulations on public procurement and how such regulations impact purchasing for care and purchasing of care.

•     Are able to reflect on the importance of purchasing in their own organisations so that they can collaborate, as a non-purchasing professional, with the purchasing department to contribute to the overall performance of their organisation.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89350,2019,Healthcare Procurement & Value Chain Management,Engels, Nederlands",Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,"['A Oortwijn', 'prof.dr.ir. EM van Raaij']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Health care providers are dependent on suppliers for the production and delivery of the services they provide to their customers. In the same vein, health care financers (such as health insurers) are dependent on the health care providers to supply health care services to their clients. In both cases, the purchasing function has the responsibility to secure external inputs (goods, services, knowledge, people) from the suppliers against the best possible conditions.

In the health care supply chain, we distinguish between purchasing of health care and purchasing for health care. When we speak of purchasing of health care, the health care is the product that is purchased (e.g., care or cure purchased by health insurers). When we speak of purchasing for health care, we are looking at a broad spectrum of goods and services needed by health care providers, such as medical devices, temporary labor, catering, and much more. Health care represents a considerable portion of public (and private) spending, and therefore, various entities (such as the WHO, as well as the Dutch NZa and RVS) are pointing towards professional purchasing management as a possible contributor to cost containment, quality improvement, innovation, and productivity enhancement in the health care sector.
In this course, we connect management theory in the area of purchasing and supply management to the specific characteristics of the health care sector.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Can explain the importance of professional purchasing and supply management in healthcare systems;
• Understand the role that incentives play in buyer-supplier relationships;
• Understand the importance of supplier relationship management and know the advantages and disadvantages of different types of supplier relationships;
• Understand the importance of alignment between purchasing and medical professionals and how to achieve such alignment;
• Can describe the advantages of horizontal buyer-supplier collaboration and the different types of buyer-supplier relationships;
• Understand the principles of the EU regulations on public procurement and how municipalities in The Netherlands operate under such regulations as they contract procviders of social care.

• Are able to reflect on the importance of purchasing in their own organisations so that they can collaborate, as a non-purchasing professional, with the purchasing department to contribute to the overall performance of their organisation.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Het vak Heffingen lokale overheden behandelt de gemeentelijke belastingen en retributies en plaatst dit specialistische vakgebied in perspectief ten opzichte van het gehele fiscale stelsel.

Daarbij is, naast kennis van de lokale belastingen, die veelal een geheel eigen karakter hebben, ook inzicht in de structuur van dit nog steeds groeiende belastinggebied van belang. De verbondenheid van de belastingverordeningen dient kritisch te kunnen worden beoordeeld. Gegeven de veelvuldige wijzigingen (ook in dit deel van het belastingrecht) dient inzicht te worden verkregen in de materiële gevolgen van implementatie van nieuwe regelgeving, waaronder het steeds bredere gebruik van de WOZ-waarde, bijvoorbeeld in de inkomstenbelasting en in de vennootschapsbelasting (de beperking van de afschrijving op gebouwen ingevolge de Wet Werken aan Winst).

Heffingen lokale overheden richt zich op een uitwerking van diverse belastingen en rechten die gemeenten, provincies en waterschappen heffen, alsmede op de Wet waardering onroerende zaken, haar uitvoeringsregels en de taxatiemethoden.
Daarnaast komt de toepassing van rechtsbeginselen in ruime mate aan bod, zoals de werking van het gelijkheidsbeginsel en het evenredigheidsbeginsel.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• heeft de student kennis en inzicht in de grondslagen en beginselen van het lokale belastingrecht alsmede de verhouding van dit belastingrecht tot andere rechtsgebieden
• heeft de student grondige kennis en inzicht in de essentialia van de lokale belastingen en retributies, alsmede in de werking van de Wet WOZ
• kan de student het gelijkheids- en het evenredigheidsbeginsel toepassen op de lokale belastingen en retributies, alsmede andere rechts- en fiscale beginselen toepassen
• heeft de student kennis en inzicht in de totstandkoming en inhoud van verordeningen en lokale belastingen, alsmede in de heffing en invordering van deze heffingen
• heeft de student kennis en inzicht in de maatschappelijke rol van het lokale belastingrecht en de acceptatie van burgers van deze heffingen
• kan de student juridische teksten, waaronder wetgeving (mede hieronder begrepen verdragen), jurisprudentie en wetenschappelijke literatuur begrijpen, analyseren en kritisch beoordelen
• kan de student binnen een bepaalde tijdsspanne antwoord geven op fiscaalrechtelijke casus uit de lokale belastingpraktijk in de vorm van een schriftelijk stuk

• heeft de student vaardigheid opgedaan om te komen tot een onderbouwde juridische argumentatie met betrekking tot de werking van rechtsbeginselen, essentialia van belastingen en de werking van de Wet WOZ, en de bewijsvoering

• heeft de student inzicht gekregen in de werking van het fiscale bestuurs(proces)recht door analyse van WOZ- en andere fiscale bezwaar- en beroepsprocedures en door oefening van argumentatie in die procedures

column1: The fashion industry is a paradigmatic sector of post-industrial economies, whose products increasingly rely on symbolic and aesthetic considerations as well as on local heritage and specificities. The fashion industry revolves around a myriad of key locations around the world, yet this has been the case for an extended period of time. A polycentric geography of fashion emerged, integrating traditional supply chains with digital technologies. Some luxury brands, such as Louis Vuitton, are even engaging with blockchain to prove the authenticity of their products. Topics covered in the course, among others: place, space and heritage in the fashion industry, storytelling, craftsmanship, temporary fashion clusters, and policies for fashion. In particular, storytelling appears to be an important tool for the fashion industry due to the necessity to differentiate the various products or brands and to add emotional value to them. Heritage and tradition are at the core of storytelling. Even new fashion products and brands are imbued with a historical flavor and sense of legendary quality, with the help of storytelling and revived craftsmanship. Given the rise of sustainability concerns, storytelling and craftsmanship, and in general heritage, are gaining momentum for the fashion industry and other creative industries too.
·         The  maximum  number of students  is 30.

·         A maximum number of 10 students will be accepted from the MA Cultural Economics and Entrepreneurship and MA Place, Culture and Tourism. It is not allowed to follow Heritage and Fashion together with Economics of Fashion, Design and Architecture.

column1: Het moderne subject als autonoom en rationeel individu werd geboren in de gedachten van Descartes en Kant, zo wordt beweerd. Maar tijdens de 20e eeuw tot heden trekken veel filosofen de vrijheid, rationaliteit en coherentie van het subject in twijfel. Is het subject wel zo autonoom en vrij als het meent te zijn? Is het wel wat het denkt dat het is? In welke mate zijn we bepaald door de maatschappelijke, culturele, economische en politieke aard?

In deze cursus zullen we nagaan hoe het huidige beeld van de mens als een autonoom, rationeel individu zich heeft ontwikkeld en op welke grenzen het stuit. We bespreken klassieke teksten uit de subjectfilosofie en analyseren de kritiek aan deze posities van denkers uit de 20e en 21e eeuw waaronder Freud, Nietzsche, Sartre, De Beauvoir, Lacan en Žižek. Daarbij zal duidelijk worden dat niet enkel het concept van het subject, maar ook het filosofische denken zelf altijd ingebed ligt in omstandigheden van maatschappelijke, culturele en politieke aard en dat die elkaar over en weer beïnvloeden.

column1: Leaders are key players in organisational functioning because they critically affect the people they work with — both inside and outside of their organisations. Leaders are in a unique position to motivate employees to deliver excellent performance, engage employees for the organisations’ mission and vision, and ensure alignment with societal interests. Meanwhile, leaders may also be a primary source of conflict and demotivation. Some of their behaviour may incur major organisational and societal costs. Therefore, it is important to understand how leadership can bring out the best in people, as well as how leadership may go wrong.

This course explores theories, research, and practice of leadership effectiveness to build a deeper understanding of the key issues in the psychology of leadership and leadership processes. Taking a collaborative learning (co-learning) approach, the course aims to generate an iterative cycle of knowledge sharing, reflection, and experimentation. Students will learn to reflect on and apply leadership research insights to evidence-based practices. Major themes of the course include core and state-of-the art leadership theories, leader-follower relationships, leading with ethics, and challenges in leadership.</body>

column1: The discipline of sociology was established during (and to make sense of) the process of modernisation. A core characteristic of modernisation is rapid social change, and sociology theorises and studies such changes by comparing traditional societies to modern societies. The perspectives that were developed and the topics addressed by the founders of the discipline are still relevant today, because they regard issues as socioeconomic inequality, social order and deviance, the role of religion and ideology, gender relations, what it means to live in an urbanised world, the relation of individuals with society. In this course we learn about these classic perspectives by looking at contemporary societies. We will learn to apply the ‘sociological imagination’ to everyday life as well as study the classic sociological questions using present-day cases. Assessment consists of a final exam and an essay.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

After this course, students will be able to describe and apply the three most important sociological perspectives (functionalism, conflict sociology, symbolic interactionism) to issues such as modernization, inequality, cohesion and individualization.

In addition, students are able to reproduce the meaning of and theory formation around the following key concepts: Scientific paradigms; Identity performance; Political distrust; Gender segregation in the labour market; Deviance and social problems; Religion and Atheism; Sociology of Globalization.</body>

column2: <title></title>
