column1: The past is not simply gone. It permeates people's lives through memory and imagination, and offers an orientation in time. Telling stories about what happened in the past plays a key role in the construction of personal and collective identities. Creating a historical narrative through emplotment means establishing a sequence of selected historical events that makes the events meaningful to a contemporary audience in a specific way. Tragic stories of historical injustice fuel calls for reparations or for emancipation. Governments go to great lengths to control historical narration and interpretation to legitimize the political entities they govern, or to legitimize their policies. Also individuals historicize their own lives through narration in order to deal with expected and unexpected challenges and opportunities.

A central concept to understand these and similar processes is historical culture. The concept refers to historical narratives and performances, to the infrastructure of the historical field which makes it possible for people to deal with past, and to different conceptions of history that enable historical imagination.

This course provides theoretical reflection on historical culture and discusses methods, such as the use of various time concepts, and the making of narrative plotlines. We will study several cases, such as analysing the narrative scripts of historical reconciliation committees, comparing the politics of descent in political speeches, and the politics of historical periodization.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Students can explain the meanings of historical culture in the context of a globalising world, based on relevant conceptions of time and narrative theories, both orally and in writing.

• Students can interpret articulations of transforming social and political attitudes towards the past in various sources and can present their interpretations with philosophical and historical arguments.
• Students are able to recognize different elements of historical narration, including composition, narrative plot and methods.

column1: Images can have a major mobilizing force. For instance, cartoons of a lazy stadholder William V encouraged the Dutch patriots to rebel against the Orangist family; and in the late 1960s, photo's about the Vietnam war in   the  newspapers  triggered  mass  protests  against  the  American  government.  The same goes for representations of a shared, contested, or imagined past. These images of the past can evoke feelings of recognition, resistance or nostalgia, and can be used to educate, entertain, commemorate, unite, or to mobilize people.

This course focuses on the process of historical representation  and imagination since the late 18th century, as well als on the  contents, narrative,  functions and  impact of historical representations. We will discuss some interesting case-studies in which we apply the concepts from the literature. Students will elaborate on the concepts and their applications in the form of written work and a group presentation.</body>

column1: The Research Workshop extends across terms 2 to 4 , preparing the students for writing their master’s thesis and guiding the writing process. This workshop comprises all phases, from writing the thesis to presenting the final result. Students choose their own research subjects within the broad overall theme of the Research Workshop. -  discussion of literature as an introduction to the theme
-  one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
-  critical discussion of the research proposals
-  discussion of and information on possible research methods
-  discussion of case studies and other work in progress
-  one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
-  discussion of case studies and other work in progress
-  one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
-  presentation of the thesis research at master conference in June
The final grade will be determined at the end of term 4.

The term Creative Industries is a relatively recent concept coined in the late 1990s by new labour in Britain. Ever since this contested concept has evolved into an important policy instrument of national and local governments, the European Union, and United Nations, as well as a lively academic discourse. In this workshop we will critically assess the impact and the implementation on a local, national and supranational level of this contested concept of this policy instrument. Academic texts will be compared with policy and consultancy texts, and the concept will be discussed in a historical, social and economic context. Finally, the workshop aims to historicize the concept and explore the historical roots of the creative  industries and how it is embedded it local contexts. It aims to analyse different sectors  of  the  industry, including (e.g.  fashion,  art markets, film, radio, television, music, design, theatre, tourism and video games), urban development and the resilience of cities, the blending of old and new cultural venues, and the rise of vibrant nightscapes.
Further information at the Thesis Market in October

column1: <body>The philosophy of information investigates critically the conceptual nature and basic principles of information, including its dynamics, utilization and sciences. In this course, we study the history of the philosophy of information from its origins in Peirce’s theory of symbolic communication (as part of semiotics), over contributions to cybernetics and artificial intelligence by a.o. Turing, Shannon and Weaver, Searle and Dretske, to Luciano Floridi’s recent project to elaborate a unified and coherent, conceptual frame for the whole subject.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: (1) The student can recognize and define the main notions, distinctions, problems and “isms” from the history and philosophy of information.
(2) The student can identify and apply the main views, arguments, objections and authors to episodes, cases and excerpts from the history and philosophy of information.
(3) The student can formulate, situate and justify the student’s own opinions on key issues in the history and philosophy of information.
(4) The student can develop and defend a view on the presuppositions and positions of media and communication studies, in relation to the history and philosophy of information.
(5) The student is able to analyse, situate and describe an episode from the history of the philosophy of information.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Until the 19th century trade was additional. Production focused on local consumption. The Industrial Revolution resulted in the use of mineral raw materials that could not locally be produced. Consequently, trade became more intense. At the end of the 19th century, the then for substantial parts colonialized countries of the Southern hemisphere supplied the West with raw materials. After World War II trade became more and more trade in diversified industrial products among the Western countries, but from the 1970s on, outsourcing and a change in policy in the South, resulted in a complete change not just of trade, but even of industrial production. The splitting up of the chains of production over a number of localities, often organized by multinational companies, not just caused an enormous increase of trade, but also in a huge growth of industrial production in previously backwards, and therefore low-wage areas. Consequently, trade grew again faster than production. The theories of international economic relations, from the ideas of Ricardo, Heckscher and Ohlin, Stolper and Samuelson, till the concepts of Krugman, the ideas on monetary policy, on international finance and on political interference in international economic relations will be discussed to see whether these can explain developments.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

·        Students can explain that in the 19th and 20th century international trade grew much faster than the global economy, that trade and economic growth are related and how the period of the World Wars and the Great Depression undermined this development, and so international trade.
·        As a consequence, they can recognize the results of political interference in international economic developments. From the 1970s, however, economic globalization recovered.

Students can interpret the general development in international trade in the last two centuries, using some basic theoretical concepts on economic trade, open-economy macro-economics, monetary relations, stable and floating currency rates, FDIs.

This course deals with constructs of culture and of cultural difference in modern history within the context of European, European expansion and colonial order as well of in the context of diaspora and migration. Principal concepts such as “culture” and “identity” “nationality” and “citizenship” will be critically reviewed, tracing its uses in the various contexts. The following twin notions will be dealt with: culture-identity, difference-equality, majority-minority, native-migrant, insiders-outsidershyperdiversity vs uniformity.
Further information at the Thesis Market in October 2019.
Note: The maximum number of participants is 8.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/88795,2019,History of Early Modern Societies,Engels, Nederlands","Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['DLA Velthuizen - Velthuizen, MA', 'dr. DR Curtis', 'dr. JC Nierstrasz', 'drs. TA Pronk']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: In the early modern period, Western societies set their first steps towards modernity. In this process, they ultimately set off on a path diverging from the rest of the world. Most historians will agree on this part of the story, but it is still under debate how, why and when this divergence started. Did it    start with the American war of independence, the French Revolution and the Industrial Revolution or had the wheels of change already been set in motion long before? Did Europe feel born again as it set out to discover the unknown after the Plague? Were the religious 'dark-ages' eventually  enlightened by the Renaissance and reason? And to what extent did international trade provide the inspiration for and precede industrialisation? During this course, it will be critically assessed whether these changes were indigenous to Europe or should be viewed just as much as a result of Europe’s interaction with the rest of the world. In the lectures and tutorials, we will ask ourselves the question if historians have too easily projected their view of the world today on the past, instead of seeing early modern societies as different and unique in their own right.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Students are introduced to the history of early modern societies between 1300 and 1750. They will acquire new insights into the structural changes that took place in Europe and in the wider world during this period. Students are able to analyse historical argumentative texts and use this skill of the so-called structure analysis in producing papers and an oral presentation.

column1: The history of economic thought helps us to understand why economists think they way they do today. It describes how theoretical frameworks have changed over time.

column2: • Classical school
• Marginalism
• Neo-classical school
• Keynes
• and more recent economic approaches.

column1: Lectures/seminars provide a general overview of the history of economics, with more detailed analysis of particular issues and problems, the precise coverage sometimes being varied to reflect the interests of those taking the course each year. Students are expected to read recommended materials beforehand, so that the lectures can focus on a discussion of the readings.

Topics likely to be covered (subject to students’ interests) include: Adam Smith, the market and trade; The Marginal Revolution – and “neoclassical” economics; Keynes, and the Keynesian Revolution; The rise of mathematical economics; The 1970s and after; Economics and other social sciences; Economists on method; Ethics and Welfare; Economists and ideology (and specific institutions).

Readings are selected to introduce students to a range of approaches to the subject. For example, Adam Smith is used to show how reading an economist through the lens of modern economics may be to impose ideas foreign to his or her thought; the lecture on Keynes introduces the idea of approaching the history of economics through an economist’s biography. Subsequent lectures give examples of work that debunks myths and which shows how changing philosophical presuppositions can change the way economic arguments are constructed.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: By the end of this course, students should be able to:
1) Explain how economic ideas may be influenced by the context in which they arose and may reflect philosophical values and attitudes different from our own.
2) Provide and comment on examples of different approaches to writing the history of economics.

3) Identify and analyse some of the major themes that historians of economics have identified, such as the “marginal” revolution, the transition from interwar pluralism to postwar neoclassical economics, the Keynesian revolution, or the recent turn to applied economics.
4) Explain, using one or more examples, how the historian’s perspective on episodes in the history of economics may differ from that of a modern economist.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>From the middle of the eighteenth century, the industrial revolution, the spread of Enlightenment ideas and the rise of Romanticism, and the political revolutions in America and France created a structural transformation of Western Europe. A core notion that emerged, and that will serve as our central theme, is the contested idea of progress: the belief that humans are able to understand the world and improve it on the basis of that understanding. Each week we will focus on a specific theme that illustrates this basic idea and its critics. The first week is devoted to the rise of the new interventionist state from Napoleonic France on, the beginning of what would later be called the welfare state. During the second week we will study class conflicts in the nineteenth century, in connection with the increasing internationalization of the economy. Week three is devoted to the crisis of democracies during the interwar period, with a focus on the rise of fascism. In week four we will study the making of the modern material environment, especially the world-wide impact of modernist architecture, design, and city planning.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course provides an introduction to the history of western societies since 1750. Structural changes in politics, culture and the economy are discussed. In addition, students are trained to close-read and interpret primary sources from this period and to report their findings in oral and written presentations.</body>

</style>

column1: Week 1. In intellectual history, few areas have recently been the subject of such intense scrutiny as the history of political thought. During the first week/part of this course the so-called ‘Cambridge School’ will be discussed. Established by eminent practising historians such as Quentin Skinner, J.G.A. Pocock, and John Dunn, it rose to prominence during the 1960s and 1970s, inspiring intellectual historians far beyond political theory.

Week 2. With his enormously influential political philosophy, Plato (c. 427-347) tried to solve the problem of conflicting interests of different parts of society. We will how his quest for harmony produced a detailed vision of an ideal society in The Republic; and we will discuss whether this vision entailed a totalitarian nightmare. Aristotle’s political philosophy revolves around the notion of man as a political animal who needs the political entity of the polis (city-state) in order to realise a happy and virtuous life; we will study Aristotle’s ideas for the best form of government and we will also critically examine his arguments for the inclusion and exclusion for certain specific groups.

Week 3. Though not very well-known for his political standpoints, Desiderius Erasmus’ Philosophy of Christ would form the basis of a standpoint on the ideal society that shares many aspects with what is understood by the rule of law in ‘free’ societies today. His moral conception of politics contrasts sharply to what we find in his friend Thomas More’s famous book on Utopia. Both positions and their intricate interdependence will be addressed. Without any doubt the best-known and most notorious work of the Italian humanist and philosopher Niccolò Machiavelli (1469-1527) is Il Principe (The Prince), first published in 1513. Notorious, because The Prince can be interpreted as a manual for would-be dictators whose goal is to attain and maintain power at all cost. Less notorious and famous, but certainly not less interesting is Machiavelli’s later more elaborate work, especially his Discourses on Livy (1531), where the classical history of ancient Rome forms the background stage of a discussion on how to form and maintain a republic. By comparing both works the students will learn about the basic principles of Machiavelli’s political philosophy.

Week 4. In the 19th century J.S. Mill (1806-1873) is the forefather of modern liberalism and feminism. According to On Liberty (1859) the greatest threat to personal liberty is no longer the state as in classic liberalism, but ‘public opinion’, which enforces conformity. Karl Marx (1818-1883) is the source of both social-democracy and communism. In the Communist Manifesto (1848) he outlines a ‘materialist’ theory of society, which sees society not as an integrated whole, but as a contingent set of conflicting groups (classes), and he links society to economy.

column1: ‘The state’, still by large providing our normative societal framework, is at best only two centuries old. However, concepts through which such a collective is described – such as nation, fatherland or republic – can be traced back much further. Differing from their modern meanings, these have already always conveyed notions of commonality; ideas of shared roots, values or interests.

Starting deep in the Middle Ages, this course traces how such notions of collectivity began to challenge feudal order. This, on its turn, was based on rather straightforward Germanic ideas about hierarchy and ownership. Should rulers not foremost serve common interests? On what underlying principles should such interests be based? Should not the collective rather than its hierarchy define community? God long remained the benchmark of human society, yet the Reformation would crush notions of Christian unity and demanded new ways of thinking.

Conflict will be at the center of attention in this course. Especially during wars, revolts or revolutions parties presented new concepts of society – to de-legitimize opponents – or defended existing ones. A fascinating journey through European history: from the conquests of Charlemagne, via the wars of religions and romantic and nationalist revolutions, to the establishment of nation-states. Towering thinkers such as John of Salisbury, Erasmus, Grotius or Locke will participate in this journey.

Hereby, focus of this course will lie on the interaction between institutions and law on the one hand – the ‘hard’ side – and thought, culture and identity on the other – the ‘soft’ side. Thereby much attention will be given to representation of power – in art, architecture or literature – and the underlying concepts of order these conveyed. Paticipants will write a paper in which an example of such representation is interpreted.

Despite having become a globally dominant form, the European or ‘Western’ conception of public order does certainly not present the only form. More so, at the start of the 21th century many of its underlying assumptions seem under pressure, both externally as internally. This course will help to understand the stakes.
Hierarchy, liberty, political body, sovereignty, honour, legitimacy, rule of law, natural law, nationhood, citizenship, representation, constructivism

column1: Why is violence against government considered a major crime? Why have citizens equal rights? Why are state and religion separated? Why are private opinions private? Why does one feel Dutch, or possibly European?

Answering such questions is looking for the origins of our public order: the way society is structured and the parameters by which we arrange our lives. These do not simply exist, yet are all human constructs and always the result of some or another agreement. This course looks, over a long period, at the roots and rise of modern public order. Students thereby not only learn to understand long-term historical processes and how these interacted, yet also gain a deeper understanding of our current society. </body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course History of Western Arts and Culture provides a historical and chronological overview of Western art and culture from the late Middle Ages until the 21st century. Students get acquainted with the major developments in the visual arts, architecture, music, and literature from this period, against a historical background. It is demonstrated how the highlights from these disciplines originate from, reflect, and shape the socio-cultural context of their time, and how these historical developments continue to have their effects on contemporary culture.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

History of Western Arts and Culture is intended for first-year students of the International Bachelor Arts and Culture Studies/Algemene Cultuurwetenschappen. The aim is to provide them with a historical and versatile foundation for their further studies. Students will acquire a historical overview of the main developments and trends in Western art and culture, and gain insight into how the various disciplines (visual arts, literature, architecture and music) are interrelated.  Furthermore, students will gain insight into the way in which art comes from, reflects on, and at the same time shapes the socio-cultural context of its time. Finally, students will acquire knowledge on how the position of the artist in relation to fellow artists, clients and the public has developed historically.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86957,2019,History of the Art Market,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. EG Mannheimer', 'LJLM De Strooper, MA']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course will provide an introduction to the history of the Dutch and European art markets, and the way the art trade functions as an intermediary between artist and audience. Various aspects dealing with the production, distribution and consumption of art will be discussed. Attention will be given - among other topics - to the innovations that were introduced to expand the market for works of art since early modern times. For instance the development and growing importance of art auctions from the seventeenth century until the present will be examined in detail, as well as other more recent developments such as the impact of new media on the art market.
Note: The maximum number of participants is 55.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The course seeks to familiarize the students with the history and functioning of early modern and modern art markets. They will be exposed to the recent findings concerning the socio-economic, but also the cultural and sociological framework in which works of art were and are produced, traded and consumed. An interdisciplinary approach will be pursued in order to gain insight into these phenomena.</body>

column1: The Research Workshop extends across terms 2 to 4, preparing the students for writing their master's thesis and guiding the writing process. This workshop comprises all phases, from writing the thesis to presenting the final result. Students choose their own research subjects within the broad overall theme of the Research Workshop. A thesis market is organized before the start of term 2, whereafter students select one of the Research Workshops and research themes on offer. Every Research Workshop is structured in the same way:

column2: • discussion of literature as an introduction to the theme
• design of a research proposal
• one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
• carrying out  research
• critical discussion of the research proposals
• discussion of and information on possible research methods
• discussion of case studies and other work in progress
• one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
• wrapping up research
• discussion of case studies and other work in progress
• one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
• presentation of the thesis research at master conference in June

column1: -  participation in discussions following presentations The final grade will be determined at the end of term 4 .

History and memory are analytically distinct, but overlapping concepts. The significance of both concepts is closely related to the emergence of nation states and their colonial empires, and to the professionalization of the pursuit of history. In this course we discuss the relationship between history and memory, and how this relationship has changed over time due to fundamental changes in society, such as the French Revolution, the emergence of mass culture, secularization, two world wars, new media, globalization, and transformations in historical scholarship. We will also study specific applications of these concepts in examples of (popular) historical culture, such as the construction of the nation state, heritage and public history.</body>

column2: • Students can adequately and efficiently structure and conduct historical research
• Students can critically assess and discuss the research design, data collection and methodology of their master’s thesis
• Students can analyse, report and present their research findings
• Students can present their ideas and work- in-progress
• Students can constructively comment on the research of their peers

column1: De psychologie is een breed vak met verschillende subdisciplines, zoals sociale psychologie, persoonlijkheidspsychologie en ontwikkelingspsychologie. Tijdens deze minor maken studenten kennis met een aantal psychologische fenomenen uit het leven van alledag. Voorbeelden van vragen die aan bod komen zijn: hoe betrouwbaar is ons geheugen? Heeft het zin om hard na te denken, of kun je beter op je intuïtie vertrouwen? Waarom wordt de ene persoon topsporter en de andere niet? Wat is normaal en abnormaal? Kunnen sommige mensen echt de toekomst voorspellen?

Deelnemers aan deze minor krijgen een bloemlezing van onderwerpen uit de psychologie voorgeschoteld (denk aan geheugen, persoonlijkheid en leren). Verder wordt een historische overzicht van het vakgebied gegeven. Ook wordt aandacht besteed aan de methodologie van de wetenschappelijke psychologie. Aan het eind van de minor zal de deelnemer onderscheid kunnen maken tussen wetenschappelijke kennis en psychologische huis-tuin-en-keuken inzichten. Verder dienen studenten zich enkele praktische vaardigheden eigen te maken, zoals het interpreteren van een psychologische test en het kritisch lezen van een wetenschappelijk artikel. Bij wijze van rode draad komen de volgende onderwerpen aan bod: 1) Ken uw klassiekers (de geschiedenis van de psychologie en de methode), 2) Ken uzelf (hoe werken psychologische tests?), 3) Ken uw beperkingen (de psychologie heeft aangetoond dat wij mensen beperkt zijn in onze rationaliteit; deze beperkingen worden behandeld in verschillende colleges).
Elke week is er een college. Rondom dat college dienen schriftelijke opdrachten te worden gemaakt. De onderwerpen zijn als volgt (onder voorbehoud).
3. Hoe doe je een goed psychologisch onderzoek?
De opdrachten worden in het laatste college plenair nabesproken.
Verder vindt er een inzage plaats na afloop van het vak.

column1: The study of anatomy (and morphology) is crucial in understanding how multiple tissue types and organ systems are organised in multicellular organisms, and how they interact. Moreover, it is not possible to understand how such organisms ‘work’ (as studied in physiology) without having a fundamental anatomical knowledge. Clearly, this knowledge is also vital when studying the nature of a disease (pathology) as well as the biological mechanisms that lead to disease (pathogenesis).

In this course, we will focus on the anatomy of humans. You will learn the exact location, three-dimensional orientation and morphology of all major human body parts, and you will learn the correct anatomical language that is required to describe these parts. Particular attention will be given to the cardiovascular, respiratory, gastrointestinal, nervous, and musculoskeletal systems. The course is designed in tight collaboration with the Erasmus MC, and consists of expert lectures, interactive tutorials, and dissection room practicals, which ensure that you will get a practical, hands-on learning experience.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • obtain a general understanding of the use and importance of general anatomical nomenclature (in Latin and/or English);
• learn to actively use the terms in the anatomy checklist to describe the basic anatomy of the bony skeleton and its joints;
• be able to relate the dermal and musculoskeletal system of the extremities to its nervous innervation;
• be able to explain how musculoskeletal system allows the movement and stability of the human body;
• be able to identify and describe the basic anatomy and functional properties of the anatomy of the thorax;
• learn how to describe the main characteristics of the human blood circulation and name the main arteries and veins of the human body;
• be able to identify and describe all the abdominal and pelvic organs and know where they are located in the abdominal and pelvic cavity, respectively;
• learn the basic functional anatomy of the human nervous system and head and neck structures.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In deze cursus gaat het over human enhancement, ook wel ‘mensverbetering’ genoemd. Nieuwe (bio-)technologische mogelijkheden die  in eerste instantie bedoeld zijn om ziekten te genezen, kunnen ook worden ingezet om de menselijk vorm, het functioneren of bepaalde capaciteiten te verbeteren voorbij dat wat we ‘normaal’ of ‘gezond’ noemen. Deels zijn dit soort toepassingen nog hypothetisch en futuristisch, deels al realiteit.
Het debat over de wenselijkheid van deze ontwikkelingen is fel en vaak sterk gepolariseerd. In deze cursus worden verschillende posities in dit debat besproken en met elkaar geconfronteerd.

Na een algemeen overzicht en positionering van het debat in wetenschappelijke, historische en filosofische context, wordt specifiek ingegaan op enkele cruciale begrippen en argumenten in het debat: natuurlijkheid, menselijke natuur, het leven als ‘gift’, de spanning tussen controle en acceptatie, en het principe van ‘procreative beneficence’.
Tijdens het onderwijs zal behalve aandacht voor de inhoudelijke argumenten ook aandacht zijn voor de verschillen in stijl en benadering tussen de diverse auteurs.</body>

• De student kan uitleggen hoe de begrippen natuurlijkheid, menselijke natuur en ‘giftedness’  worden geïnterpreteerd en gebuikt door verschillende auteurs binnen het human enhancement-debat
• De student kan uitleggen wat het principle of procreative beneficence is, en welke kritiek daarop mogelijk is.
• De student kan een eigen beargumenteerde visie geven op (aspecten van) human enhancement.

column1: Human physiology studies how cells, tissues, organs and organ systems function in a healthy human body in response to internal and environmental changes. An important focus point of this course is homeostasis, i.e. the maintenance of the steady state of the body within the narrow ranges that are compatible with life. You will learn that homeostasis is regulated at multiple levels, from the cellular to the organismal level. To understand these levels of regulation, it is crucial to study the structure and function of various tissues and organs in the human body. Therefore, histology – the study of the microscopic structure of tissues – is also part of this course. The systems under scrutiny include the central and peripheral nervous system, the circulatory system, the respiratory system, the musculoskeletal system, digestive system, urinary system, and the endocrine system.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The physiology of systems under scrutiny include the integumentary system, the nervous system, the circulatory system, the respiratory system, the musculoskeletal system, digestive system, renal system, and the endocrine system. The immune system will be studied in detail in Quad 4, 200-level course, 'Micro- and immunobiology', and is therefore not a focus within this course.
Learning objectives regarding the biological systems under study include:

column2: • Be able to recognize different histological tissue samples from one another.
• Be able to describe the structure and identify characteristics of the organs’ tissues and relate them to their functioning.
• Know the normal vital physiological parameters.
• Understand how these vital parameters are regulated/ kept constant under normal and extraordinary circumstances (e.g., microgravity, high altitudes, cold temperatures).
• Be able to make and present a scientific poster in a clear and attractive way.

column4: This module focuses on the strategic level of HRM: how can we use HRM practices to achieve long term viability for (public) organizations. Notwithstanding this strategic orientation, the importance of ‘tactical’ HRM (e.g. which HRM practices ‘work’ and why) will be also dealt with. The first part of the module will discuss the theoretical background of strategic HR: what is it and why is it important? In

the second part several more concrete themes (e.g. training, work design, motivation, leadership) will addressed using recent academic literature. Although the focus will be on ‘general mechanisms’, students will be asked in this part to reflect on the usability of these mechanisms in the context of a developing country. This reflection will be supported by a discussion of several academic articles about HRM related themes in developing countries.

column2: </body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: This course introduces students to key theories, concepts and empirical findings about HRM in the public sector. The course aims to provide students with an understanding about what HRM is, and how it can be applied in order to motivate employees. After the course students should be able to apply general HRM theory and insights to the context of developing countries.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89476,2019,Human Resource Management,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. A Burmeister', 'dr. CISG Lee', 'dr. JPJM Essers', 'dr. M van der Giessen', 'dr. RL Hewett']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In many industries, the personnel – or the Human Resources – of an organization are one of the most vital factors shaping an organization’s success or failure. Decisions that involve the hiring, training, job assignments, or the exit of employees have far-reaching consequences. These consequences do not only involve financial gains or losses and have potential legal implications for the organization but also affect individuals and their motivation and ability to be productive and satisfied. Effectively managing a company’s Human Resources thus requires an appreciation of how people-decisions are shaped by and shape individuals’ motivation, well-being, productivity, and identification with the organization they work for.

This course offers you an evidence-based and multidisciplinary perspective on the main challenges in Human Resource and People Management. We begin by examining the conceptual foundations of Human Resource Management including the key strategic role of successful HR management, the design of jobs and work processes, and the conditions under which work is satisfying and engaging. We then focus on the hiring process all the way from the human resource planning to sealing the deal with new hires and starting the socialization process. Building on this, a number of sessions deal with how one can achieve great results with the people within an organization by motivating and compensating their efforts, measuring their performance, as well as training and developing them for current and future tasks. Considering the final stage in the employee lifecycle, we will then consider how to manage employee’s voluntary and involuntary exit from organizations. We finish the course by considering the critical role of people analytics in modern HR management, and reflecting on the latest challenges in HRM. Throughout this course, we will highlight interesting cases that illustrate how these techniques and practices work out in organizations. By the end of the class, you will therefore have a deep understanding of and basic hands-on experience with regard to the most important HR practices in light of the empirical evidence that supports or discourages their use.

Given that Human Resource Management is a central organizational function that supports many other functions (e.g., human resources are needed to realize strategic plans) this course has links to many other courses in your curriculum. Of particular importance are the courses of Organizational Behaviour which laid the foundation for many of the concepts we will apply to workplace settings in this course and the course on Organizational Theory & Dynamics as the effectiveness of Human Resource practices is often contingent on how well it is aligned with the broader organizational structure.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After following this course, students will be able to

column2: <li>
Describe and explain fundamental HRM practices and their theoretical underpinnings.
<li>
Recognize and link this knowledge to practical people management problems and challenges.
<li>
Integrate theoretical knowledge and practical considerations to critically analyse and suggest solutions for people management problems and cases.
<li>
Reflect on the role of evidence in guiding the actions of HR and people managers.
<li>
Employ basic people management techniques and skills in your own workplace interactions.

column1: At the end of this course you should have acquired or improved your skills in the following areas:

column2: • Analytical thinking;
• Problem identification and problem solving;
• Working in groups and group dynamics.

In iedere organisatie is het 'managen' van personeel een belangrijke managementstaak. Theorieën over Human Resource Management proberen dit aspect van het managementsproces zo goed mogelijk te laten verlopen ervan uitgaande dat 'de mens de bron is van het succes van een organisatie'. Hoewel dit zonder twijfel voor zowel publieke als private organisatie geldt, kent de toepassing van HRM in de publieke sector een aantal specifieke problemen en aspecten. In de module zal daarop nader worden ingegaan, waarbij actuele thema's op het terrein van HRM worden besproken, zoals diversiteit, ontwikkeling van loopbanen en Het Nieuwe Werken.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

• Kunnen uitleggen hoe je met de inzet van HRM-instrumenten houding, gedrag en prestaties van werknemers in de publieke sector kan beïnvloeden.
• Kunnen formuleren van een onderbouwd onderzoeksvoorstel op het gebied van HRM in de publieke sector
• Kunnen opstellen van een HRM gerelateerde beleidsnotitie voor een publieke organisatie

column1: This course addresses the various legal instruments and monitoring/enforcement mechanisms for the international protection of human rights, placing emphasis on the United Nations and its various organs, as well as regional organizations (with a main focus on the Council of Europe and its European Convention on Human Rights). After a brief but intensive study of the key underlying doctrinal debates in human rights and its connection to international law, students will comprehensively examine the principal international human rights treaties, enforcement systems, and illustrative case law.

The different instruments and protection mechanisms are explored in relation to contemporary debates regarding the concept, scope, development and – obstacles to the actual – enforcement of human rights.

The course aims at enabling students to identify the relevant actors, instruments and monitoring/enforcement mechanisms for the international protection of human rights. Furthermore, students successfully completing this course will be able to analyse recent trends and developments in the context of that framework and critically assess different points of view in relation to the application and interpretation of human rights. Students will also train their analytical, writing and debating skills by participating in the compulsory Seminars.
Accordingly, students successfully completing this course will be able to:
-    Independently analyse and assess, in the context of broader public international law, human rights treaty law;
-    Independently analyse and assess, in the context of broader public international law, legal problem statements pertaining to the implementation or enforcement of international human rights law;
-    Develop ways, in cooperation with others, of addressing human rights problem statements with profound societal ramifications;

-    Independently present, in both oral (viz., in the form of moot court pleadings) and written (viz., in the form of written memorials) form, the results of academic research as well as legal advice, both to other lawyers and to a non-legally trained audience.</body>

column1: This course is open—by invitation only—to IBCoM’s most talented and highly motivated students. Once they are invited to the course, interested students must submit a special application. A limited number of applicants can be accepted in the program.

CM2100 gives excellent students access to opportunities and challenges beyond the normal scope of an undergraduate program. Honours students are exposed to the most recent developments in communication and media studies. Moreover,  various and attractive fieldtrips, as well as close contact with professionals, organizations and experts give students the opportunity to witness and, in many cases, actively engage in real life communicative and media practices within public and private institutions. Students’ own contribution in the HP’s curriculum—through engagement in class discussions, presentation of their own work, building of a portfolio and the organization of the honours symposium —further enables them to actively explore new areas of interest.
The course is organized in two modules, and an honours symposium at the end.

column1: The first two decades of the 21st century have witnessed a considerable reduction of poverty and associated phenomena in countries previously labeled as “under-developed” countries. The rapid and widespread innovations, mostly enabled and  driven  by  Information  and  Communication Technologies (ICTs), have given rise to “Emerging Markets”, also known as “Emerging Economies”. More and more developing countries are making remarkable inroads into economic growth and some have even become global leaders in specific areas. The introduction of the Internet, followed by the advent of mobile telephony, has been instrumental in driving innovation in vital sectors such as education, healthcare, economic livelihood, and local entrepreneurship, to mention a few areas. ICT and Innovation scholars project not only more ICT-driven innovations in emerging markets, but also the transfer from those innovations into developed countries (reverse innovation).

This seminar offers students a critical, analytical, historical, and practical insight into the various ways in which Emerging Markets have been taking advantage of the development process to become central to the ICT-driven innovations. Students historically explores the transition from the previous approach, one that was mostly centred on international development policies, to the current home- grown, ICT-driven innovation approach to poverty alleviation. In this seminar, students get an insight into real-life ICT-driven innovations that involve various actors (e.g., local startups, NGOs, governments, multinationals) and in different areas and sectors. The seminar focuses on the following key areas: education (in the broader sense), healthcare, rural entrepreneurship (income- generating activities), economic livelihood, and banking (and related services). While exploring these areas, students are invited to go beyond the surface (the hype) to critically consider underlying concepts such as power, gender, sustainability, inclusiveness, and ethics.
Note: The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 25. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

column1: How can information and communication technologies (ICTs) be used to create societal impact and promote social change? The advent of Interned-based communication, social media, online platforms and communities, has created new opportunities for organizations and businesses to mobilize large online crowds to exchange information, gain resources, obtain new skills and knowledge, and eventually achieve social change. While there are several examples in academic research and practice of the use of technologies for social purposes, it is also important to develop a critical understanding of the effectiveness of these practices and their societal impact.

This course offers a unique combination of topics at the intersection of sociology and business information management to understand new organizational forms produced by ICTs and aiming at social change. We will analyze and discuss how ICTs can be used as a possible way to raise awareness about and find solutions to some of the world’s most challenging social problems across a range of domains (e.g., sustainable development, health, environment, public and social sector, activism). In addition, we will also critically analyze advantages and disadvantages of ICTs use for social purposes.
By studying cases from academic, empirical research on the use of technologies for social change, this course will also offer an opportunity to

column2: • Understand the importance of conducting research with a societal impact by connecting the creation of knowledge with possible practical applications or solutions to social problems.
• Understand and reflect upon the use Big Data and computational methods to conduct research that is important for society.

column1: Practically, this course will offer insights about

column2: • How we, as citizens, can directly engage and collaborate in the solution of societal problems via an effective and responsible use of ICTs.
• How organizations and businesses can make effective use ICTs for social good.
<title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The main learning objectives of this course are:

column2: • Discuss, analyze and critically evaluate how information and communication technologies (ICTs) are used to create societal impact and promote social change.
• Critically identify and analyze advantages and disadvantages of ICTs use for social purposes.
• Develop an understanding of the basics of sociological theory related to social change and social problems.

• Identify and analyze some of the most challenging social problems across a range of domains and develop an ability to critically think and create possible solutions to the problems via the use of ICTs.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

</style>

column1: In this IFPSM/IPSERA Summer School, the emphasis is in educating participants on the (classical) management theories suited for studying research questions related to Purchasing and Supply Management. Since the 1960s, Purchasing and Supply Management (PSM) has developed from a predominantly administrative process into a strategic function of the firm. While one could argue that the academic literature has reflected developments in practice, or perhaps even has helped stimulate some of these developments, there is still debate how one could best define what exactly constitutes PSM research. It is our view, based on the developments PSM research has gone through the five decades since its emergence in the 1960s, that PSM research is most appropriately seen as a multi-disciplinary field. Acknowledging this diversity, and mapping the patterns of prevalence and influence over time, could help raise our understanding of the historical development of PSM research, and may provide helpful insights regarding future development opportunities.

Each of the six interactive lectures (sessions) will be hosted by a different faculty member. Faculty consists of international top scholars both from the PSM field itself, but also from contributing disciplines, primarily Strategy & Organisation, Marketing and Operations Management.
For admission and registration, please refer to the ERIM website.

</style>
• Analysing the historic development of the PSM research field
• Understanding the differences and similarities between contributing mono-disciplines to PSM research
• Knowing the main theoretical frameworks from the respective disciplines, and their respective contributions and limitations
• Being able to identify appropriate theories for addressing new research questions

column4: Stage 1: Developing ideas for the Master thesis and gaining proper background knowledge of the field of study

This stage starts around the end of the second semester. It involves the exploration of a research topic for the Master thesis.  Research topics are typically linked to the themes provided by IM/CEMS professors. Students select the theme or research area of their liking and write a 5-page research proposal framed around a research question linked to this theme or research area (for more details on the proposal – see below). The draft proposal provides the input for the second stage, i.e., the Research Clinic.
Stage 2: The Research Clinic: refining ideas and the research proposal

The Research Clinic constitutes the formal start of the research semester. The objective of the Research Clinic is twofold. First, to enhance the student’s understanding of the process and methods of international business and management research. Second, to assist students in applying this knowledge and methodology to their own research project. The seminar informs students about how to formulate a research question, how to develop a theoretical framework, look for relevant studies, develop testable hypotheses, select adequate research methodologies, to interpret research findings and to draw conclusions from research findings. The Research Clinic is structured around plenary lectures that address these issues; in parallel, students will be working in small-scale highly interactive work groups applying these themes to their own research topic. Groups will typically consist of students sharing similar research topics. The output of this seminar is a research proposal for the Master thesis.

Participation in the Research Clinic requires that students have submitted a draft proposal before the start of the Research Clinic. At the end of the Research Clinic, students submit their definitive research proposal. Grading of the Research Clinic will be based on the draft and the final proposals only according to the following criteria:
a. Quality and sophistication of the draft proposal (25%)
b. Quality and sophistication of the definitive research proposal (75%)
c. Attendance; attendance of group and plenary sessions is mandatory.
Grading criteria that will be used for the (definitive) research proposal:
•Relevance: is the research question relevant and interesting for international managers, companies and scholars?
•Theoretical sophistication and problems exploration: does the paper indicate a proper understanding of the relevant theories and prior empirical research in the area?
•Methodological rigor: Is there an appropriate explanation and selection of research design and methodology?
•Feasibility: Is the study feasible in three months? Are data sources available and accessible?

Students who are unable to secure a 5.5 as a grade for their definitive research proposal are provided with feedback, and a second deadline to revise and resubmit their proposal. Note however that students who are unable to pass on their first attempt can only expect to get a maximum mark of 7 on their second attempt (and 5.5 on their third attempt). Changing topics/supervisors after the research clinic will not change these rules.
Stage 3: The Master thesis: Conducting the study and writing up and presenting research outcomes

This third step implies the implementation of the research proposal. In practice, it involves conducting the empirical study, processing and analyzing research findings and writing the thesis. Students and supervisors will continue to meet on a regular basis in order to address and solve common problems and issues, and to discuss research and exchange ideas.
Completion of this stage marks the official end of the MSc curriculum. After finishing the thesis, most students will be ready for MSc graduation.

column2: </body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: The principal objective of the Master thesis is to familiarise students with carrying out business and management research and to allow students to gain a deeper understanding of a topic of their interest. As such, the thesis contributes to the student’s specialisation in a particular area. Knowledge and understanding of business and management research is relevant in both business and academic settings. Training in business research methods prepares students to systematically investigate and solve a management dilemma (i.e., any problem or opportunity that requires a management decision) and to evaluate whether studies and proposals prepared by third parties (e.g. consultancy agencies) can serve as a basis for a management decision.

Through the Master thesis process students will also develop their competencies and skills in writing and communicating their ideas. Finally, time management and self-management are important managerial skills, which the thesis period provides an excellent opportunity to develop and test.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89087,2019,Idea Management,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. JP Madiedo Montanez', 'prof.dr. DA Stam']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In a knowledge-based and innovation-driven business environment, managing ideas is an essential capability if an organization is to gain a sustainable competitive advantage. All innovations begin with ideas and managing these ideas is needed during the entire innovation process. Employees in any job and at any level of the organization can contribute to innovation with creative ideas.

This course takes place as part of the master in Management of Innovation. After general courses concerning innovation strategy and organization of innovation it is the first of a series of two courses that follow the temporal order innovation in the innovation funnel: Fuzzy front end (this course: idea generation, selection and communication), and Implementation (course 2: projects and teams).

This course consisst of three components. First students will learn more about creativity in general and how to make (groups of) other people more creative. The course will cover creativity tools such as brainstorming and systematic inventive thinking. In the second part, students will become familiar with some of the quantitative tools used to support decisions in the management of innovation. Furthermore, students will recognize some of the some of the most common biases that affect idea evaluation and discuss strategies available to improve idea selection decisions. During the final part, the discussion will turn to what happens with creative ideas. Generating ideas for the sake of generating ideas is not enough; instead, the focus of the idea management process should turn to answering how people can get others to see the value of their ideas by communicating ideas in an effective manner.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course will enable students to understand and apply the fundamentals of an idea management process that includes generating, evaluating, selecting and communicating ideas. At the end of the course students will be able to leverage concepts, theories and tools related to creativity, decision making and communication for supporting and advancing the management of innovation process in different contexts.

column1: <body>Today’s culture is a visual culture. Since the 1970s, the social sciences and the humanities have increasingly turned their attention to the many ways in which visual technologies and images have come to play a central role in the construction of the shared meanings, or mental representations, through which our social practices are structured. Images reproduce power relations as much as they can contest dominant ways of seeing, and thinking about, the world. In this course we will analyse representations of class, gender, race and sexuality that circulate in the media by discussing and applying various key texts and methodologies from the fields of media studies and cultural analysis. Students read foundational texts by authors such as Marshal McLuhan, Roland Barthes, Stuart Hall, and Laura Mulvey in a weekly seminar and apply various visual methodologies in order to analyse a self-selected set of images in our weekly workshop.</body>

column1: Does a university degree raise your future wage? Does increasing the legal retirement age maintain individuals longer at work? Does restricting the bonuses of portfolio managers lead to less risk taking? Does development aid raise economic growth? Answering such questions requires a valid method of evaluating the effect of interventions.

In medicine one patient group is randomly assigned to a treatment while others receive a placebo. Identifying the effect of treatment is then relatively straightforward. In business, economics and social policy, such randomised experiments are often infeasible, unaffordable or considered unethical. Statistical methods must then be used to estimate the effect of an intervention relative to a counterfactual. This often calls for a great deal of creativity on the part of the analyst.

This course will give a non-technical overview of the intuition behind the most frequently applied evaluation methods in economics. The students will learn the required steps in a valid evaluation, the distinction between correlation and causal effects, the assumptions of different methods and in which situation each method can be used.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>At the end of the course students will be able to:

column2: • Understand and apply a variety of impact evaluation methods
• Critically analyse impact evaluation research
<li>Draw policy implications from impact evaluation research

Does a university degree raise your future wage? Does increasing the legal retirement age maintain individuals longer at work? Does restricting the bonuses of portfolio managers lead to less risk taking? Does development aid raise economic growth? Answering such questions requires a valid method of evaluating the effect of interventions.

In medicine one patient group is randomly assigned to a treatment while others receive a placebo. Identifying the effect of treatment is then relatively straightforward. In business, economics and social policy, such randomized experiments are often infeasible, unaffordable or considered unethical. Statistical methods must then be used to estimate the effect of an intervention relative to a counterfactual. This often calls for a great deal of creativity on the part of the analyst.

This course will give a non-technical overview of the intuition behind the most frequently applied evaluation methods in economics. The students will learn the required steps in a valid evaluation, the distinction between correlation and causal effects, the assumptions of different methods and in which situation each method can be used.

The main concepts are introduced in the first five weeks. The second part of the course is devoted to a group assignment, which will consist of a critical assessment of an existing evaluation, providing suggestions for improvement, and implementing these suggestions yourself. The students will hand-in a written report.</body>

• Critically assess an existing policy evaluation/academic paper that aims to estimate causal effects.

• Estimate causal effects using statistical software for the most often applied Impact Evaluation techniques (multiple regression, matching, fixed effects, difference-in-difference, instrumental variables, regression discontinuity).

column1: SMART cities use technology, in particular information and communications technology (ICT) and big data, to better manage cities. If well governed, these technologies are expected to lead to major efficiency gains. The use of smart technologies is growing in popularity, with many governments jumping on the bandwagon to become a “Smart City’. The use of technology is also of great interest to the private sector, who sees the opportunity to innovate and to have access to lucrative business opportunities. Creating smart city policies is difficult as the concept of smartness is diffuse and contested. What is smart in Rotterdam, may not be smart in other urban contexts. In addition, government organisations in developing countries often lack the required capabilities and resources to use technologies in an integrated, safe and inclusive manner. Authors argue that smart technologies can favour a small group, leading to increased inequality and what Richard Florida refers to as an ‘urban crisis’[i]. Smart cities can therefore lead to exclusion and disempowerment.

However, smart technologies can also be empowering and inclusive. In self-organized processes, communities frugally innovate and find local solutions to local problems. Examples are the use of apps to inform communities of jobs, disasters, subsidies or safety risks. Smart technologies can improve social capital of the urban poor. However, frugal, inclusive and smart innovations tend to be place and time specific; they are hard to upscale. This is of particular importance when the pressures of rapid urbanization demand large scale solutions to include and empower the urban poor.

This situation creates a tension: there is a distinct disconnect between the efforts of local governments at the city wide level and communities at the local level. The ultimate question is: how can multiplex governance arrangements of new technologies include and empower all urban residents at scale at a time when those same technologies push people out? The top-down and bottom-up SMART paradigms need to meet, leading to a new conceptualization of and approach to Smart Cities.

column2: • Definitions, technologies and governance arrangements
• Evolution of the Smart City concept
• Case studies
• Critical reflections
• Frugal, inclusive innovations
• Self-organisation
• Critical reflections
• Top-down and bottom-up governance arrangements
• Strategies and tools for co-creation, such as living labs and citizen science.
• Multi-level perspectives

column1: [i] Florida, R. (2017). The new urban crisis: gentrification, housing bubbles, growing inequality, and what we can do about it. Oneworld Publications.

column1: After the module, participants should be able to:

column2: • Discuss, compare and critically reflect on the different concepts underpinning Smart Cities and Smart Inclusive Cities;
• Appreciate the trends in and impacts of smart technologies on urban management and development;
• Assess different governance responses and their relevance;
• Develop strategies and apply tools to govern inclusive smart cities.

column1: Bij Indirect Tax Assurance and Technology gaat het om het begeleiden en beheersen van fiscale processen en risico’s als onderdeel van de totale bedrijfsvoering en bedrijfsstrategie en om de inzet van nieuwe technologieën daarbij. Van een incident-gedreven en fiscaaltechnische aanpak naar een (nog) meer procesmatige en risicogerichte benadering. Doordat indirecte belastingen transactie- gerelateerd zijn, neemt het belang van een dergelijke benadering steeds meer toe. Het fiscale beleid van de onderneming speelt een belangrijke rol in dit vak. Bezien vanuit de belasting- en douaneautoriteiten, is het van belang om kennis te nemen van dit beleid en de implementatie daarvan. Concepten als ‘AEO’ (Authorised Economic Operator) in het douanerecht en ‘CTP’ (Certified Taxable Person) in de BTW nemen dan ook in belang toe. Niet alleen fungeren zij als een kwaliteitskeurmerk richting de belasting- en douaneautoriteiten, maar voor de betrokken bedrijven verlenen zij ook toegang tot vereenvoudigingen in diverse regelingen.
Dit vak brengt de studenten op de hoogte van de ontwikkelingen op bovenomschreven gebied.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Na het volgen van dit vak is de student:

column2: • op de hoogte van de ontwikkelingen omtrent tax assurance & technology;
• in staat om fiscale processen omtrent indirecte belastingen en de fiscale risico’s die daarmee gepaard gaan, in kaart te brengen;

• bekend met de digitale technologie die kan worden gebruikt bij de fiscale risicoselectie en risicobeheersing ten aanzien van indirecte belastingen en in staat deze technologie te gebruiken in praktijkgerichte cases;
• op de hoogte van ethische leerstukken omtrent fiscaliteit en de invloed daarvan op de fiscale werksfeer en in staat om daarin zelfstandig een positie te bepalen.

column1: Het vak bouwt voort op de theorieën die zijn behandeld in het derdejaarsvak Economics of Taxation uit de Bachelor Fiscale Economie en het tweedejaarsvak Openbare Financiën uit de Bachelor Fiscaal Recht.

Na een algemene inleiding over de inzichten vanuit de welvaartseconomie en de gedragseconomie ten aanzien van de effecten van belastingheffing (verstorende invloed/deadweight loss, tax incidence, internaliteiten en externaliteiten) in de eerste week dat als een rode draad geldt voor specifieke onderwerpen in het vervolg van het blok, wordt in de daaropvolgende weken telkens een actueel onderwerp met betrekking tot indirecte belastingen behandeld. Het vak beoogt daarmee ook een economische kader te bieden bij de bestudering van vakken die zich richten op specifieke onderdelen het indirecte belastingrecht.

In week 1 wordt een algemeen kader gegeven van economische inzichten op het gebied van belastingheffing in het algemeen en indirecte belastingen in het bijzonder. Vanaf week 2 van het blok wordt een specifiek onderwerp op het gebied van indirecte belastingen ingeleid door een gastdocent.
Sessie 5               Belastingen op vastgoed door Bas Jacobs
Elk groepje studenten schrijft een beleidspaper over een onderwerp naar keuze, onder de restrictie dat dit onderwerp geen betrekking mag hebben op het toegewezen te organiseren werkcollege.
Aan het eind van week 6 worden telkens gedurende 15min de beleidspapers ‘gepitched’ waarna een korte discussie volgt.
Voor de hoorcolleges en het pitchcollege geldt een verplichte aanwezigheid.
Het eindcijfer wordt voor 40% bepaald door de kwaliteit van het beleidspaper en de pitch en voor 60% door het tentamenresultaat.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Het vak brengt de student op de hoogte van de (recente) ontwikkelingen in het economisch denken over verschillende kenmerken van het (Nederlandse) belastingstelsel in het algemeen en indirecte belastingen in het bijzonder en ontwikkelingen in het fiscaal beleid op het gebied van indirecte belastingen.

Bovendien daagt het vak studenten uit het belastingstelsel op het gebied van indirecte belastingen te evalueren en eigen ideeën, gebaseerd op economische theorie, te ontwikkelen over hoe het belastingstelsel op het gebied van indirecte belastingen optimaal kan worden georganiseerd.
Na het volgen van het vak:

column2: • Zijn studenten geïnformeerd over de actuele beleidsdiscussies over indirecte belastingen;
• Kunnen studenten het (Nederlandse) belastingsysteem op het gebied van indirecte belastingen op basis van argumenten uit de economische literatuur evalueren;
• Kunnen studenten actief deelnemen aan beleidsdiscussies door het combineren van hun kennis van het fiscale recht en de economische theorie.

column1: <body>This course focuses on the processes of individualisation and globalisation, which have transformed western societies virtually beyond recognition since the second half of the 20<sup>th</sup> century. As this is a course in sociology, a key question is what the sociological study of these processes entails. What do sociologists mean by individualisation and globalisation? How do they measure such wide-ranging processes? And what do they focus on in theories and research dealing with individualisation and globalisation? A second key issue entails assessing the consequences of individualisation and globalisation. Combining sociological theories and empirical research findings, students will learn to critically examine the impact of globalisation and individualisation on various domains of social life, such as communities, politics and consumption. During the interactive sessions students will focus on applying their knowledge to real life cases. The course is assessed through a final exam and an essay.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Explain how sociologists conceptualise and measure individualisation and globalisation;
• Explain theories about the impact of individualisation and globalisation on various domains of social life, such as communities, politics, and consumption;
• Explain the similarities and differences between various sociological theories on individualisation and globalisation;
• Apply sociological theories on individualisation and globalisation to contemporary social phenomena;
• Critically reflect on sociological theories on individualisation and globalisation.

column1: <body>This course provides an overview of modern industrial organization that blends theory with real-world applications. It acquaints the students with the most important models for understanding strategies chosen by firms with market power and shows how such firms adopt to different market environments. Formal theory is complemented throughout by real-world examples that show how it applies to actual organizational settings. The main analytical tools will be microeconomic theory and game theory.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Information technology (IT) is revolutionizing the way people and firms transact business. This process is only being accelerated with the development of social media and the availability of big data, which has enormous impact on our activities and the way organizations work and compete. This rapid movement towards the new information economy is being led by both established firms such as Wal-Mart, General Electric, and new entrepreneurial firms such as Google, Amazon, Facebook, YouTube, and Dropbox. As a master student of business information management, you need a thorough understanding of the latest technology trends, how firms embrace disruptive technologies, and what new business models emerge that allows firms to compete and lead in the information economy. This course will devote to the study of the strategic use of information, and provide you with the understanding of the role of information, the closely related role of information technology, major developments of e-commerce, and their implications on economics, marketing, and operational issues. This course will focus on problems unique to information-intensive businesses that you will soon encounter as a consultant, analyst, technologist, or entrepreneur.

The course is a combination of lectures and a high degree of case analysis and discussions. In the class, you will work with real world examples ranging across different industries. The course will cover six themes: information strategy, business model and digital transformation, business-to-consumer e-commerce, electronic markets and auctions, information goods, and platform mediated networks.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
The objective of the course is to help you to:

column2: <li>

Develop an ability to discuss how the presence of IT enables new business models and how digital transformation changes industry structure, and alter marketing, sales, operations, and business practices.
<li>
Learn the contemporary issues in e-commerce, the changes in consumer behavior, and the opportunities for different forms of electronic markets and auctions.
<li>
Describe pricing and versioning of digital goods and recognize the importance of platform mediated networks.
