column1: This course examines corporate governance practices from an international and multidisciplinary perspective. Corporate governance deals with the mechanisms through which control is exercised over corporate managers. How do suppliers of finance (i.e. shareholders) make sure that managers do the right thing and do not steal the capital or invest the capital in bad projects? During this course the main topics of corporate governance will be discussed. The focus is on legal aspects of corporate governance. Among the topics to be discussed are:
- The definition of corporate governance; the separation between ownership and control; Agency costs theory;
- The functioning of boards of directors; the role of outside directors and one tier and two tier boards;
- The role of executive compensation and the market for corporate control (hostile takeovers);
- Shareholder rights, shareholder activism and shareholder litigation;
- Corporate governance codes; securities regulations; monitoring by state agencies;
- Comparative corporate governance: developments towards convergence especially between the US and the EU.

column1: <body>Upon completion of this course students will be able to:

column2: • Understand the significance of corporate governance issues
• Understand the way corporate governance issues are regulated
• Value the rights and responsibilities of both shareholders and the board of directors
• Understand the significance of internal and external monitoring
• Independently analyze and solve legal questions concerning international corporate governance, including questions concerning regulation, board structure, takeovers and remuneration

• Work in a team in order to analyze critically on how the current legal framework, relevant to the fields of international corporate governance operates and evolves and to provide a well-reasoned opinion of his/her own

column1: <body>The course, which is set squarely within the field of public international law, examines both the international rules governing states’ assertion and exercise of their respective national criminal jurisdictions and the body of international law relating to international crimes (such as genocide, crimes against humanity, war crimes, torture, slavery, piracy, and the wide range of treaty crimes loosely described as ‘terrorist’) and international criminal courts (from the International Military Tribunal at Nuremberg to the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia and the International Criminal Court).</body>

column2: <title></title>

</style>

column1: ‘International law typically governs the rights and responsibilities of States; criminal law conversely is paradigmatically concerned with prohibitions addressed to individuals, violations of which are subject to penal sanction by a State. The development of a body of international criminal law which imposes responsibilities directly on individuals and punishes violations through international mechanisms is relatively recent’ (Cryer et al, 2014, at 1).

Within the framework of the regime of international criminal law various international criminal courts and tribunals have been established in order to assess individual criminal responsibility at the international level, including the International Criminal Court, International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia and the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda. Attention is paid to the jurisdiction and procedure of these international tribunals, as well as to the definition of the four core crimes, namely aggression, genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity, and the distinctive modes of liability.

Regard is also had to the various fields of international law that influence the on-going formation of international criminal law, particularly international human rights law and international humanitarian law.

column2: <title></title>

column1: <body>After successful completion of the course, a student will be able to independently:

column2: • describe, analyze and assess the essential principles governing international criminal law as well as the various bodies and procedures through which international criminal law is being institutionalized;
• describe, analyze and assess  the relationship between international humanitarian law, human rights law and national and international criminal law.
• apply the essential substantive and procedural principles of international criminal law to hypothetical cases and deliver well founded legal advice; and
• conduct academic research relevant to international criminal law and based on this, provide a well-reasoned opinion of his/her own.

column1: This course will examine international dispute settlement in more depth, and with emphasis on inter-state judicial institutions, such as the International Court of Justice, and state/on-state dispute settlement. The opening lectures will address themes such as the concept of “international dispute”, the obligation to resolve disputes peacefully, the matrix of available dispute settlement options and the role and specificity of judicial dispute settlement mechanisms. Subsequent lectures will be devoted to the norms of “international legal procedure” governing international tribunals, with a focus on the International Court of Justice. The remaining lectures will turn their attention to the examination of specific judicial institutions, cross-cutting issues such as the independence and selection of judges and arbitrators, the role of the current dispute settlement “architecture”. Specific institutions which will be discussed include ITLOS, the WTO DS system and other mixed dispute settlement bodies, such as ICSID.

column1: The process of globalization is evolving around various international economic institutions; this course discusses these institutions in a critical and rigorous manner. We will start with a brief introduction to the international economic order and the main rationales underpinning the legal institutions for trade liberalization and global economic integration. The course will further zoom-in on the legal system established by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) and the World Trade Organization (WTO), as well as on the system of Bilateral Investments Treaties (BITs). We will begin by exploring the principle of non-discrimination, embodied by the most favored nation clause and the national treatment, on which WTO law rests and which is also embedded in BITs. Students will be further introduced to the dispute settlement procedures of the WTO and of Investment Agreements. The mutual interplay between WTO law, Investment Law, environmental law and human rights law will also be analyzed. The course Next to studying already established International Organizations and institutions, the course will offer insights into the conclusions of megaregional agreements, such as the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) between Canada and the European Union.

column2: <title></title>

</style>

column1: The goal of the course is to provide students with knowledge of the international economic legal system. Great emphasis will be placed on case law, so as to enable students to confidently navigate this field of law. Also, the course aims at training students in presenting their work and in engaging in academic discussions concerning the on-going process of globalization. Students who actively participate and successfully conclude the course will master the knowledge necessary to work in an international environment and will develop the analytical skills crucial for a critical appraisal of the legal-economic dimensions underpinning the globalization process and the role of these dimensions in the development of the international legal order.

column1: Why are some rich, while others remain poor? How have international trade, states, institutions, and (human) capital flows affected economic growth? These are some of the key questions that economic history deals with. Since 1500 the world has seen a wide variety of economic developments, such as industrialization, imperialism and colonialism, waves of globalization and deglobalization, and the rise and fall of economic centers. Transportation and communication technologies have created a smaller world with a higher level of economic interdependence.

These developments have had profound impacts on the economic development of regions around the world. Apart from war and treaties, the field of international relations also includes this economic dimension through trade, investment and other monetary relations. This course focuses on international trade and the development of international monetary systems. Furthermore, economic policies have varied over time, ranging from mercantilist power politics to international economic collaboration and from free trade to protectionism. This course addresses the questions that underpin global economic history and introduces theories from the field of international relations, including Realism, Liberalism, Constructivism, English School, Marxism, and Neoliberal Institutionalism.

column2: <title></title>

</style>
• The student understands the most important international relations theories: Realism, Liberalism, Constructivism, the English School, Marxism, and Neo-liberal Institutionalism.
• The student has basic knowledge of global economic history.
• The student understands and can explain that periods of protectionism and free trade alternate in the course of modern history.
• The student understands various economic theories on the differences between rich and poor regions and nations.

• The student understands the conflicts of interests that can exist between different economic actors, including multinational and national companies, entrepreneurs, local, national and transnational governments.
• The student understands the concept of a national economy and its limitations
• The student understands the concept of economic growth and is able to reflect on the advantages and disadvantages of using this concept as a measure of prosperity and well-being.

column1: International economics deals with issues raised by the interactions between countries. It can be divided into two major parts: international trade and international finance. The first deals with the real side of international economic relations, i.e. the exchange of goods and services, and answers questions like: why do countries trade? What do they trade? What are the consequences of trade, and how is it regulated by policy? The second deals with the monetary side, i.e. the exchange of assets, and focuses in particular on how the exchange rate between two currencies is determined.

Although macroeconomic quantities are at the core of the analysis, these will usually be built up from a microeconomic perspective. The nature of the subject implies that international economists frequently find inspiration elsewhere for their applications, for example from geography, econometrics, development, monetary economics, industrial organisation, etc. This approach results in a rich diversity of insights, nonetheless characterised by a remarkable coherence.
The purpose of this course is:

column2: • To understand the basic theories and concepts in international trade and international finance.
• To gain knowledge about the world economy as such and the economic interactions between countries.
• To understand that the macroeconomic relations at the core of the analysis of international economics re usually built up from a microeconomic perspective.

column1: <body>International environmental law (IEL) is an innovative, dynamic, and rapidly developing field that seeks to ameliorate global environmental issues such as the impacts of climate change and marine pollution/exploitation. As the causes, effects, and potential solutions of such global phenomena transcend national boundaries, international cooperation is increasingly important as reflected in a growing number of international environmental agreements governing disparate issues such as nuclear testing, hazardous substances, and atmospheric pollution. This course aims to provide students with an overview of the evolution of international environmental law, as well as an introduction to the major concepts, cases, and principles that shape effective global environmental governance. Throughout the course, attention will be focused on international responses to environmental issues with a transboundary or global scope. Following the introductory lectures, which will set the scene by introducing the major players (international institutions and actors) in the field, students will have an opportunity to explore the role of international law in regulating environmental problems such as marine pollution, climate change, nuclear testing, as well as the governance of outer space, the Arctic, and Antarctica.</body>

column1: Since the end of World War II, the international investments and other foreign activities of companies and individuals have grown substantially, and this growth is accelerating in recent decades. Firms of all types and sizes now face decisions about how to best obtain and allocate resources abroad. Furthermore, significant differences in economic development between countries have persisted, and these give rise to considerable variation in the prevalence of market imperfections. Consequently, basic financial decisions now involve cross-border complexities. This course examines key issues in international finance, focusing on recent developments and incorporating theoretical, empirical, policy, and institutional dimensions. We will approach each topic from four perspectives: theory, policy, global risk, and implications for the multinational firms and investors.

The first part of the course will cover the modern international financial markets architecture including, in particular, currency and capital markets, international investments, economic and financial integration and globalization. We learn to understand and interpret the data on capital and trade flows, the balance of payments and global imbalances and get familiar with the key economic concepts in the context of a globalized economy.

We will begin the core of the course by discussing how financial globalization affect the pricing of internationally traded assets and how international investors allocate their asset portfolios. A canonical general equilibrium model of Lucas (1982) will be introduced to conceptualize the discussion about international asset pricing. Equipped with the key relationships from this model we will review the extensive empirical literature testing whether equity returns depend upon a set of common world factors. We will find that the pricing of internationally traded assets continues to depend strongly upon local risk factors, investors exhibit a strong home bias in equity portfolios, and there is a premium associated with the international cross-listing. We will try to reconcile this evidence with the models that incorporate country-specific idiosyncratic risk and behavioral and informational asymmetries.

We will proceed with the topic of exchange rates - the key international financial variable and one of the sources of global financial instability. We will describe the behavior of foreign exchange returns, putting them in the theoretical framework introduced in lecture on asset pricing. The most studied foreign exchange anomaly is the forward discount bias, the phenomenon that the forward rate predicts the wrong sign of future movements in the exchange rate. We will go over the models of exchange rate determination built to generate their observed behavior and related empirical evidence. The related topics include the microstructure of foreign exchange markets and the issues related to the choice and coordination of exchange rate regimes, including the European Monetary Union.

The third topic relates to international investments at macro level. The key scholarly and policy debates in this area relate to the benefits and costs of financial globalization, global macroeconomic and financial imbalances, and the transmission of currency, economic and financial crises and policy response. The case in point is the 2008-09 financial crisis and the on-going sovereign-debt crisis.

Finally, we will touch upon selected issues related to the international activities at micro (firm) level. The forces of globalization have fundamentally changed the scope and activities of firms. In particuar, we will discuss why firms choose to export or produce abroad (become a multinational) and hoiw they organize this production.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

• Understand and explain key theoretical principles explaining the interrelationships between economies in the globalized world. Understand and interpret macroeconomic concepts in the context of a globalized economy.
• Understand of the mechanisms that determine the evolution of the global economic environment and its influence on domestic financial markets.
• Understand the behavior and summarize the main determinants of exchange rates as the key international financial variable and one of the sources of global financial instability.

• Get familiar with the scholarly and policy debate about the benefits and costs of financial globalization, global macroeconomic and financial imbalances, and the transmission of currency, economic and financial crises and policy response.

• Understand the reasons for emergence and examine the role of multinational firms. Learn about decisions, risks, and practical issues facing companies participating in international markets. Analyze and discuss financial problems corporations face that result from operating in an international environment.
• Read and critically evaluate academic and policy papers related to international finance.
• Obtain, analyze, present, and interpret the relevant economic and financial data.
• Interpret the key economic news in the context of theory and empirical research covered in the course.
• Learn to apply the econometric techniques for empirical tests of the key relationships related to international finance.

This course provides an overview of the key issues in financial reporting. We use International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) and relate the requirements for each particular topic to the underlying concepts and principles. This will help you learn to make informed judgements and think critically about financial reporting problems. These are necessary skills for your future career, whether you will be preparing, auditing or using financial statements compliant with IFRS.
The course starts with a short refresher of basic of the Conceptual Framework. We will continue with more advanced areas, including:

column2: • Fair value measurement
• Financial instruments
• Business combinations and goodwill impairment testing
• Pensions and share-based payments
• Revenue recognition

column1: In this course we will reason about financial reporting primarily in a forward direction, i.e. analyse a fact pattern and decide how the facts shall be reflected in the financial statements.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
On completion of this course, students will be familiar with:

column2: • The objective of financial reporting and the main concepts as set out in the Conceptual Framework;
• The structure and style of accounting standards and the debate in key  problem areas (for example as evidenced in de Basis for Conclusions);
• The main requirements concerning recognition and measurement for the selected topics and the related IAS/IFRS.

column1: Students should then be able to:

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/88760,2019,International Health Law,Engels,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['mr. M Timmers', 'prof.mr.dr. MAJM Buijsen']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course focuses on the impact of international treaty law on regulating health care systems. Therefore, this course starts with identifying the underlying principles of health law. These principles explain the ratio of regulatory intervention in health care, i.e. good health. Good health raises questions about access to medical care, human rights and health care, scarcity of resources, mobility of patients, health professionals and medical products, and market competition in health care. For instance, who has access to health care services, what is the meaning of informed consent, and what services should be included/excluded from the basic benefit package. To a large extent these questions are influenced by legal standards as defined by international treaty law.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • The course aims at increasing knowledge of the international legal framework on human rights in health care
• The student will be able to identify, analyze and understand contemporary legal problems and dilemmas in health care access, and other patients’ rights, and apply this knowledge on similar issues
• The student will be able to identify, analyze and understand contemporary legal problems and dilemmas in allocating health care services with respect to vulnerable groups
• The student will be able to analyze and summarize court rulings on enforcing health care rights
• The student will be able to formulate relevant legal arguments in the patients’ rights debate
• The course will encourage students to develop competence in oral communication skills, in the legal dimensions of health care access and individual patients’ rights

column1: The course adopts a holistic approach to learning international human rights law, beginning from its normative foundations and emergence as a distinct field of international law to its contemporary status and challenges for the future. Given the introductory nature of this course, emphasis is placed throughout on idealism as well as realism, including an understanding of how international and domestic politics have influenced and continue to influence the field of international human rights law. On the normative side, participants will analyses the merits and demerits of categorizing human rights under different labels and its effects on human rights promotion. They will look at case studies from around the world that expose the tensions between cultural relativism and universality of human rights, and will also look at the concepts of collective rights and rights of vulnerable persons. On the practical side, participants will be introduced to the most important mechanisms as well as challenges to the realisation and promotion of human rights, including State compliance and judicial enforcement. Finally, the inter-play between nation-states and civil society will be scrutinised with a strong focus on NGO activism and the emerging challenges thereto.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Practices of journalism vary considerably, depending on the wider - local, national and even transnational (Al Jazeera, CNN) - contexts in which they take place. Departing from some of the main benchmarks in (Western) journalism with regard to training, routines, formats, organization, ethics and culture, this course familiarizes students with the field of journalism studies from the perspective of foreign correspondence and their journalistic practices across the globe. This entails gaining insight in the obstacles correspondents meet when working in non-democratic, non-free environments. This course combines theory, research and practice related to foreign correspondence. Students learn about the concrete work experiences from correspondents themselves, they learn to reflect on these experiences from an academic perspective and to relate their learned insights to international journalism in general.
Note: The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 50. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

• How and why journalistic practices and international news coverage vary across different contexts
• Analyze, compare and critically reflect upon journalistic practices using concepts and theories covered in this course

column1: This course focuses on the changing institutions underpinning the international legal order and the
emerging systems of global governance (that is governing without the traditional forms of
‘government’). International law is changing from a predominantly inter-state system of law into a
multi-actor system of law, which includes in addition to states also individuals, non-governmental
bodies, private actors and international organizations. Moreover, the role of international
organizations has changed – from coordinators of inter-state cooperation to participants in
decision-making, both in terms of normative development and decision-making in individual
Given the multiplication of relevant actors and in the absence of a central government (i.e., there is
no central lawmaker, executive or judiciary), the international legal system is multi-localized. That is,
international law is made and implemented, and disputes are adjudicated at different localities, with
the relationship between the different fields of law involved often being uncertain.
This architecture has led to what is often referred to as the fragmented nature of international law.
Despite this fragmented architecture, new ‘localities of coordination’ can be identified. It is often
argued that these ‘localities of coordination’ operate at the expense of human rights, rule of law and
democracy. This premise will be regularly returned to during the course. In addition, theoretical
approaches aimed at understanding and normatively framing ongoing developments will be
explored. These perspectives include Global Administrative Law and theories about the

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85526,2019,International Law and Regulation,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['DL van Helden, MSc', 'mr.dr. JA van Ast', 'prof.dr. P Mascini']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>By means of formulating and interpreting norms, law plays an important role in creating and upholding social order. The nation state is of great significance for law. However, nation states are embedded in larger political, legal, and economic institutions such as the EU, NATO, WTO, and the UN. The treaties and laws which are formulated at the supra national level, pertain to the domestic level as well. One of the aims of supra national legislation is to address cross border societal problems s in a unifying and harmonizing way. One can think of environmental problems such as climate change, deforestation, and pollution and work related problem s emanating from global production chains such as exploitation and unhealthy and unsafe working conditions. Such bord er crossing problem case s accrue in prevalence and magnitude as a result of a globalizing economy. So far, domestic and international legislation have had limited success in handling these societal problem s. This is one of the reasons why business and civi l society have recently become increasingly involved in the formulation, monitoring, and enforcement of standards for products and services. Moreover, the private regulation of markets interacts with law at different levels and in different ways. This cour se first deals with the fundamentals of law and the manner in which supra national law is incorporated in domestic law. What is law? What public law, civil law, administrative law, criminal law? What do important legal concepts mean, like constitution, leg ality, rule of law, separation of powers, attribution, delegation, mandate, authority, act, regulation etc. And international law, with its many regulations and institutions, what is it actually about? Subsequently, the course deals with private regulation and the mutual interaction between (international) law and private regulation. Which private parties are involved in private regulation, and how? Under what conditions are these private forms of regulation more or less likely to succeed? When do law and p rivate regulation act as substitutes? When are they complementary or conflicting? The focus is on the handling of cross national social problem case s spurred on by a globalizing economy. The first half of the course aims at answering these questions with a comprehensive introduction in the study of law. The second half of the course reflects on the changing role of law and regulation in contemporary society.  </body>

column1: <body>After following this course, the student is able:

column2: • to place conflicts, questions and issues in the different fields of law;
• to present the most important changes in terms of law during recent history;
• to reproduce the main elements of the legal organization of a Western democratic unitarian state and administration;
• to reproduce the role of law and of the state in modern society;
• to reproduce the legal background of the most important institutions in international law (EU, UN, CoE);
• to point out how international public law influences national law;
• to define some of the basic legal concepts and position these concepts in modern governance, the state, international institutional relations and in international environmental law;
• to define regulation;
• to reproduce the dominant view on recent trends in regulation in terms of actors, instruments and goals as well as the limitations of this dominant view;
• to assess the tenability of the assumption that private international regulation can close the gap that is left by public international regulation;
• to understand the relationship between public and private regulation.

<body>This course gives a basic introduction in international migration and various related phenomena. The course focuses on the causes of international migration and the consequences of international migration in both sending and receiving countries. We will discuss extensively economic and sociological theories that try to explain why people migrate from one country to another, and often from one part of the world to the other. A second major issue in the course are the consequences of migration for sending countries and communities, Does migration contribute to economic and social development in sensing communities? And what are the consequences for receiving countries, in terms of both the socio-economic (or ‘structural’) integration of migrants and the socio-cultural integration (or ‘assimilation) of migrants or lack of assimilation and resulting cultural diversity in receiving countries and communities where many migrants settle?</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Have insight in the size and character of international migration processes in various parts of the world, both in the presence and in the past
• Have solid understanding of economic and sociological theories about factors that contribute to the rise and continuation of processes of international migration
• Understand to what extent and how migration policies and migration control of receiving countries are able to steer international migration flows

• Understand and are able to take a substantiated position about whether or not, or under what conditions, international migration contributes to the economic development of and social relations in sending communities

• Understand and are able to take a substantiated position about whether or not, or under what conditions, international migration results in growing socio-economic inequality and socio-cultural diversity in receiving countries

column1: Public International Organisations, including European Union, together form the structural web of co-operative relationships between states. They have also become elements of the modern state's institutional system and of its public administration. The law of public international organisation is the body of rules, principles and concepts governing the functioning of international organisations, their interrelationships and their legal connection with the (member) states' administrations

The precise nature of the European Union (EU) remains problematic for traditional explanations of international relations. The EU is neither a state nor an international organisation. This course investigates the politics and legal measures that determine the extent to which the EU is a global actor. These concepts are evaluated in a variety of international policy areas: trade/economic policy, development/humanitarian assistance policy, the Common Foreign and Security Policy, and Common Security and Defence policy. The course also explores the EUs varied relations with other major powers: the United States, Russia and China/Asia.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After completing this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Understand the basic legal and institutional structures governing the functioning of international organizations, and thereby grasp in structural terms, the international system of which modern states operate in;
• Understand the steps of European integration, as well as the constitutional and institutional foundations of European external relations;

• Develop a proficiency in recognizing EU’s competence, tools, policy choices and role in different strands of EU external action such as enlargement, association, neighbourhood, development, humanitarian aid, trade, common foreign and security policy; and the coordination thereof;
• Analyze EU relations with other international actors from a structural and legal framework.

column1: This course assesses historical developments in the global world economy. It applies political economy theories to explain economic globalization and the need for global cooperation in the areas of trade, finance, poverty reduction and the environment. It assesses the internal governance structure of global economic institutions as well as their effectiveness. The course explicitly includes the perspectives of developing countries, both in discussing the consequences of economic globalization and in discussing the effectiveness of global economic institutions and regimes. In addition, the effectiveness of foreign aid is discussed.

column2: <title></title>

column1: <body>After the course, students are able to:

column2: • Explain and assess the nature of economic globalization and its consequences, in particular for developing countries
• Assess the need for global public goods in the areas of trade, finance, poverty and the environment

• Explain and evaluate the decision making procedures of the major existing global economic institutions and regimes, such as the WTO, the IMF, the World Bank and the (UN) Framework Convention on Climate Change
• Assess the effectiveness of these global economic institutions both in general and for developing countries in particular
• Discuss and assess the effectiveness of foreign aid
• Use and analyze data from international databases to answer simple but relevant empirical questions.

This course will be significantly different than any other course you have ever taken. Its design is such that it has features of both a course and a competitive consulting assignment. The elective covers many aspects of branding, marketing and communications in a challenging way. We focus on digital & data, corporate social responsibility & purpose and neuromarketing.
L’Oréal is offering the marketing students of Erasmus University a unique opportunity to play the role of consultant, and dive into a very dynamic, real-life, practical assignment.
At the same time, the selective is designed such that teams will be able to build inspiring and well-underpinned brand experiences by applying the right concepts, methods and techniques.

It provides the opportunity to develop marketing and consulting skills through a practical, real-life experience, the chance to work closely with professionals in their field, and the possibility of winning a contest at one of several levels. All of these can contribute to one’s clarification of what kind of professional career could be interesting to pursue (or not) in the future. Being able to discuss the experience and what was learned with future employers. The course as it is designed, is a lot of work, and a lot of fun to apply marketing and strategy models and techniques learned during their study in a real-life business situation.

• Design and conduct quantitative and qualitative research to underpin your idea;

column1: <body>The classes are constructed in line with the typical strategic management cycle. Following aspects are addressed:

column2: • Setting the scene: Weberian bureaucracy, New Public Management, New Public Governance.
• Strategy, strategic management, strategic planning as international public management tools.
• Strategy formulation and analysis: Guiding elements, instruments and political mandates.
• Strategy implementation: Performance measurement/management, policy alienation.
• Strategy evaluation: Accountability and the learning organization.
• Intermezzos: Case studies of international public and nonprofit organizations.
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The general goal of this course is to provide students with the necessary tools to become a manager within international public and nonprofit organizations or to be able to understand typical managerial jargon they might be confronted with when working in such an organization.
This general goal is divided into three sub-goals:

column2: • The course seeks to offer students both knowledge of as well as insight into the strategic management of international public and nonprofit organizations. In doing so, the course centers on strategic management as (a) an integrated management cycle consisting of strategy analysis, formulation, implementation and evaluation as well as (b) a social process consisting of complex interactions between managers, professionals, clients and politicians.

• The course addresses the strategic management of international public and non-profit organizations as a practice, something that (international) public managers ""do"" as opposed to solely something they ""have"". This implies that the course also aims to provide students with the necessary creative and analytical competencies to apply, in team, the concepts and frameworks taught in the course on concrete cases of international public and nonprofit organizations.

• The course seeks to present students with some of the ""strategic issues"" they are likely to be confronted with when working as an (international) public manager. This includes the global macro-level evolutions within the management of public organizations (i.e. Weberian bureaucracy, New Public Management, New Public Governance), the concept of policy alienation as well as the importance of stakeholder participation.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87606,2019,International Relations & Human Rights Law,Engels,Erasmus University College,,['N Tilahun', 'PK Livaha, LLM', 'prof.dr. M Onderco']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
The minor will explore how governments, non-governmental organisations and international institutions interact in their efforts to protect human rights.

State sovereignty and international relations have a profound impact on the ability of the international community to respond to gross human rights violations. Thus, in this course, the positive and negative impacts of domestic politics and transnational actors and the collision of human rights ideals with the doctrine of state sovereignty will be recurring themes. Instruments of statecraft ranging from diplomacy, monitoring and mediation to peacekeeping and humanitarian military intervention are depicted and analyzed in the light of case studies.

The course will examine unresolved practical, theoretical (and maybe philosophical) issues and questions concerning the universality of human rights; whose responsibility it is to protect human rights; and whether human rights conventions, laws, and regimes are effective. Thus, the course looks at the juxtaposition of the traditional claims of states to guard sovereignty and impose order against more recent claims by individuals to freedom, rights, justice, universal moral order and humane treatment.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: 1)      Understanding the theories and issues of International Relations
2)      Understanding foundational values and basic doctrines of fundamental rights, being able to apply the latter in concrete cases

3)      Understanding the interaction between sovereignty concerns for states with ‘legitimacy concerns’ of international courts, and being able to identify the tension with the effective protection of fundamental rights.
4)      Understanding the role of interpretation principles characteristic of human rights in this regard.

column2: </body>

column1: This course provides a critical introduction to International Relations (IR) Theory for historians. It seeks to develop the analytical tools required for theoretically informed historical research into international relations. This will aid you in formulating the research proposal for your master’s dissertation. We will begin with two crucial philosophical (epistemological and ontological) questions: what is, or should be, the relationship between History and IR Theory? What ‘is’ theory, and what does it ‘do’ for us as researchers? The rest of the module will approach important current IR theories from this vantage point: realism, liberalism, Marxism, critical theory, constructivism, the English School, feminism and postcolonialism. By the end of this course, students will be able to critically engage with competing theories and place their own research within a theoretical tradition.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Students can present and discuss major theories of international relations
• Students can present and compare major theories of international relations
• Students can elaborate on the possibilities and difficulties of using IR theories for historical research
• Students can apply IR theories to historical cases

column1: The aim of this introductory course on international relations theory is to familiarise you with the concepts, ideas and analytical tools necessary to understand state behaviour and relationships between various actors in the international system. Competing analytical perspectives explaining state behaviour such as realism, liberalism and constructivism will be examined. The course will also examine alternative approaches to international relations such as Marxism, feminism, post-colonialism, post-structuralism, and Green theory. Each of these frameworks will be applied to different case studies to explore how the theory works in practice. By the end of the course you will have knowledge of international relations theory and are able to analyse a myriad of issues in global affairs from a variety of perspectives.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Students will understand how major scholars have theorized international relations; assess contributions and short-comings of both mainstream and alternative theories; enhance their analytical skills and develop capacity to engage in complex political issues; demonstrate how theory provides a road map by which to examine international events and processes.</body>

column1: This course reconstructs the development of purportedly democratic global governance from a combined historical and normative political philosophical perspective. It specifically asks: where do international organisations come from? What makes them legitimate actors in international relations? And how do these organisations themselves justify their role in international politics?

While international organisations nowadays are fully integrated elements in the landscape of international politics, until the turn of the twentieth century there was hardly any space for them, or any rationale for their existence. How and why did this change? And in what way is our post-World War II international order built on the initial emergence of international organisations?

In this course students explore the interface of contemporary political science debates and the history of political theory. Students will develop a normative reconstruction of the legitimacy of specific international institutions that in one way or another perform roles in the public space of international society with regard to the exchange of information, the organisation of discussion and negotiation over the shaping of global order in the early twenty-first century.

In the first part of the course students come to grips with the different theoretical approaches to understanding the nature of international organisations as democratic institutions and learn to reflect on the existing literature and key questions that exists in various academic (sub-)disciplines. In the second part of the course students develop a mini research project (as an individual assignment) in which they reconstruct the mission and activities of an international organization of their own choice, from the theoretical point of view that formed in the first part. Students present their results in the form of a short research paper and deliver their findings during the final student seminar at the end of the course.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>By the end of this course, students

column2: • will be able to critically reflect on the status of international organisations vis-à-vis the nation-state in global politics;
• will have developed a capacity for critical reflection on theories in contemporary political science and the history of political thought;
• will be able to analyse the discursive forms through which organisations justify their own position in the international realm;
• will have deployed the above theoretical and practical capacities in reconstructing the mission and activities of a concrete international organisation within global politics and society;
• will report their findings in a short piece of academic writing and a seminar presentation.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85854,2019,International Trade Policy,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. A Erbahar', 'M Haasbroek']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Why do countries trade? Is everyone better off from trade? Why and how do governments use trade policy instruments and how do they affect the economy? What is the role of the WTO and what can explain the proliferation of trade agreements? These are some of the questions we will explore in this course. We will begin by reviewing the traditional trade models of Ricardo and Hecksher-Ohlin, and identify the winners and losers from trade. Then we will study the instruments of trade policy and their effects. The course will then move to the political economy of trade policy to understand what determines trade policy, and we will conclude by studying the world trading system, paying special attention to the role of the WTO and regional trade agreements.
The following topics will be covered during this course:

column2: • Introduction to Trade and Trade Policy
• Comparative Advantage
• Trade and Resources
• Trade Policy Instruments and their effects
• Political Economy of Trade Policy
• Multilateral Trade Negotiations and the Rise of FTA's
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• To understand the economics of international trade and its distributional consequences.
• To learn about the most frequently used trade policy instruments and their effects.
• To understand the role of the WTO and regional trade agreements in the world trading system.
• To quantify the effects of policy actions on different groups in a country.
• To acquire mathematical skills in formalizing economic models.
• To write a research paper on a real-world issue.
<title></title>

<body>This module fosters insight in the commercial transaction. Focus will lay on the law of Agency, Sale of Goods, Documents, Financing and Transportation. Many people can be involved in an international trade transaction.  Through the concept of Agency, a person can benefit from, or be liable for, the actions of another person.  The transaction creates duties and liabilities for the parties to the contract of sale, which need to be understood.  Then, the sales price has to be paid and the goods have to be carried to the buyer.  In an international context, with parties that don't necessarily trust each other, these operations create legal challenges. Throughout these subjects the Bill of Lading  plays a central role. This document entitles its holder to claim the goods from the carrier, it serves as a title to the goods, and it will be used as security in the financing operations.  The Bill of Lading is also very important to the Customs; it is, for instance, a crucial document in the customs risk assessment of the customs declaration.</body>

4.       Apply the various concepts in analysing a complex case.

The course pays special attention to the historical, politico-economic, social, cultural, and technological factors that have shaped both (1) communication relations across the globe and (2) the way in which we think about these relations.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The International Business Project is a consultancy-like project. International teams of 3-5 CEMS students solve a real business problem as a one-semester part-time activity tutored by both the company and a professor in parallel.
Each CEMS student must carry out a Business Project during Term 2. It amounts to 15 ECTS, which is about 50% of Term 2's workload.
International business projects reinforce the CEMS partnership between universities and companies in jointly shaping the student learning process in international management.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87572,2019,International entrepreneurship: From start-up to scale-up,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. W Hulsink'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

One manifestation of our globalizing world is the emergence of innovative start-ups that have a worldwide focus and sometimes resource base from inception. The international activities of these firms that have decided to go abroad almost directly after their creation, have received an increasing amount of attention over the past years; they are called born globals or international new ventures. In addition to small and medium-sized firms with incremental growth strategies, the focus in this course is on these dynamic start-up firms that make products and sell services that are ‘new to the world’, strive for scaling up their activities and seek international presence. These growth-oriented start-ups with global expansion strategies face a lot of uncertainty compared to established multinational companies with more traditional products and services: their novel products or services are unknown to the market, so is the effect of the product for the customer. Also, in bringing these niche products and services to the international market, young firms have limited resources and few complementary assets (they do not have deep pockets and needed additional start-up and growth financing). In this course we will look how innovative start-ups and ambitious small firms mitigate the risks starting-up, early growth and internationalization, and more specifically how they address and manage their country selection and market investigation, their entry mode choice(s) and international operations and capabilities. Other interesting characteristics of these international new ventures are the importance of the founders and the entrepreneurial team, their particular motives for international expansion, and the relevance of strategic partners and investors.

The course will be composed of (guest) lectures, a case assignment, and a field project. Lectures will introduce the students to the (international) entrepreneurship literature and apply it through discussing cases on growing/internationalizing entrepreneurs and their firms in class. Guest speakers, e.g. entrepreneurs, investors, and business facilitators, will cover the more practical aspects and hands-on tactics and tricks in the domain of international entrepreneurship. Blending theory and practice will be created through doing a case assignment. In this assignment, teams of students will produce a teaching case and a teaching note on an internationalizing new venture/young firm. Students will pick and study an entrepreneurial firm in its growth and internationalization efforts, and more specifically focus on a strategic choice the entrepreneur and his/her firm has made, and prepare a teaching case and an instructor’s note for class discussion. Blending of theory and practice will also be created through the development of a field project. This includes applying the literature, collecting external data and/or contacting people for outside help, writing a report and/or running an entrepreneurial project, and presenting your work. The purpose is to work with the entrepreneurship theory in real-life situations, for example, by developing a specific checklist / roadmap for entrepreneurs or investors, producing a generic advisory report or doing a business consultancy project.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
At the end of the course, students should be able to:

column2: • identify key entrepreneurial processes (start-up and growth, opportunity identification, new venture planning, bootstrapping, etc.) and explain the key role of entrepreneurial initiative in creating new organizations and building economic activity;
• describe the leading concepts, models and tools in the field of (international) entrepreneurship, and how to transfer them to practice and apply them;
• identify distinctive characteristics of the start-up, growth, and internationalization process of young/small firms;

• recognize the opportunities and risks offered by different institutional settings of nations or regions and to understand their relevance for and influence on starting and growing of young/small firms;
• compare and evaluate (dis)advantages of different internationalization strategies (country/market selection, models of entry: exporting, partnering, joint venturing, investing, and acquiring);

• to discuss and assess the contribution of International New Ventures / Born Global Firms (start-ups/young firms searching for global niche markets) to the International Management literature and practice.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87568,2019,International strategy,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. BC Pinkham'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course will leverage academic articles, practical applications of theory, and cases to develop the students’ ability to analyze international strategy issues. Students will have the opportunity to demonstrate their understanding of core concepts through weekly quizzes and class discussion. They will end the course with a group project.

We will focus on three core theories of international strategy: Industry-, Resource-, and Institution-based views. Individually, these theories provided the building blocks for international strategy. Porter (1980) introduced what we now call the industry-based view to help managers better understand competitive dynamics in industries. In the mid 80’s and early 90’s, the revival of resource-based approaches elaborating Penrose (1952) helped to explain how firms may develop capabilities and combine and leverage resources to gain sustained competitive advantages (Barney, 1991; Dierickx & Cool, 1989). And more recently, a group of scholars has been promoting the inclusion of an institution-based view to help explain the rules of game that may shape business and firm outcomes. Together, these theories create the basis for a strategy tripod.

The strategy tripod helps managers to better understand four key questions (Peng et al., 2009): Why do firms differ? How do firms behave? What determines the scope of the firm? What determines the success and failure of firms around the globe? Each of these questions relates to firm performance, the fundamental focus of strategy practitioners and researchers and the core of our course.

I strive to evaluate all available information to arrive at a final grade that fairly reflects the student’s demonstrated capability in dealing with and understanding the international strategy course content. Evidence of this capability is recorded in this course through classroom contribution, quizzes, and a final, group report. I have attempted to strike a balance between individual and group assignments. The grade in this course is a composite of class contribution, quizzes based on case preparation and assigned readings, and a group project. I will use the following to evaluate your written and non-written work:

column2: <tbody>
</tbody>

column1: Class contribution (10%)  I will keep a record of class participation for all students and assess your contributions based on the quality of in-class comments. There will be no quantity component, and to encourage articulate and thoughtful comments I will take the highest score from the following scale to give session grades:
Marginal Quality: 1 (Overly long, confusing, or distracting comments)
Good Quality: 3 (Moves discussion along, shows basic understanding)
High Quality: 6 (Analyzes and adds to discussion)
Exceptional: 12 (Exceptional, integrates multiple sources from course materials)
In a class with our size, most comments should be Good (3) and High Quality (6). Exceptional (12) comments occur only two or three times a term.

Quizzes (50%) Students will respond to a series of True/False and multiple-choice questions each class session. The questions will be drawn from assigned readings, cases, and lectures. Some questions may extend concepts from prior sessions to emphasize differences or counter-intuitive outcomes, and may also be used to reinforce key concepts and ideas. We will leverage the quizzes in class to start discussion.

Theory and Practice (40%) Students will work in groups to deliver a presentation and written evaluation on a firm of their choice. The project presentation should include three major sections: identification of case issues(s), analysis of the issue(s), and recommendations. Your analysis should be based on the information you find through research, media articles, and field interviews. I will evaluate your presentation based on its quality and reasonableness relating to MNE strategies. I expect to see good “business presenting.” Everyone must participate in the final presentation.
(Week 41) – Bring questions to class about presentations and case write-ups
(Week 42) – Case presentations in class, final write-ups due at 5pm!
1. International strategy issue (needs to have some international or cross-border tie);
2. Follow the Case Plan Example (end of syllabus), you must write both a case and teaching note;
3. Shorter cases (5-7 pages) are always in high demand. Your goal should be close to this!
4. Delivered digitally (pinkham@rsm.nl), by 5pm on the last day of class.
Successful cases may be further developed for submission to Ivey or HBS.

Students are expected to contribute substantially to group work. Every student understands that all group members are equally responsible for the entire project unless otherwise indicated by the professor. Students completing team assignments will receive the same grade as their team members for the group report, with one exception. The professor may request each student to independently evaluate the contribution of other group members. If substantial concerns arise from these evaluations the professor reserves the right to individually assign outcomes.

Attendance of all university sessions is compulsory. If you miss a session, you must inform me (pinkham@rsm.nl) prior to the session. Students who miss 2 or more session will have their final grades reduced by 0.3 points.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The objective of this course is to develop students’ understanding of how international operations differ from domestics ones. It provides students with the necessary knowledge for a career or further study in international business.
We will focus on four outcomes. By the end of the term:
1. The student will be able to integrate both theory and practice to address international strategy cases;
2. The student will defend a choice relevant to international strategy of MNEs (e.g., location choice or entry mode) using a theory (or framework);
3. The student will distinguish between the three, leading international strategy perspectives and be able to identify the strengths and weakness of each;
4. Students (in groups) will analyze and develop/create an international strategy case to show their understanding of core international strategy concepts.

column1: <body>Het vak Internationale economie houdt zich vooral bezig met de wereldeconomie als zodanig en de betrekkingen tussen landen en handelsblokken, op het gebied van internationale handel, kapitaalstromen, economische groei, wisselkoersen, financiële verstoringen, enzovoort. Hoewel uiteindelijk macro-economische grootheden centraal staan zullen deze meestal vanuit een micro-economische fundering worden opgebouwd. Daarnaast gebruiken internationaal economen regelmatig ideeen/concepten die ook hun oorsprong hebben in andere subdisciplines van de economie (bijv. micro-/macro-economie, economische geografie, monetaire economie of ontwikkelingseconomie) Het resultaat is een rijk geschakeerd geheel aan inzichten dat helpt om de oorzaken en gevolgen van de internationale economische betrekkingen tussen landen beter te begrijpen.</body>

column2: <title></title>

</style>
• Het begrijpen van de fundamentele theorieën en concepten in de theorie van de internationale handel, maar ook in de internationale financiële wereld.

• Het verkrijgen van kennis over de wereldeconomie als zodanig en de relaties tussen landen en handelsblokken betreffende de internationale handel, kapitaalstromen, de economische groei, wisselkoersen en financiële crises.

• Verkrijgen van kennis van de macro-economische verhoudingen die de kern vormen van de analyse van de wereldeconomie, en tegelijkertijd te begrijpen dat deze relaties meestal zijn opgebouwd vanuit een micro-economisch perspectief.

• Verkrijgen van kennis over hoe de internationale economie vaak wordt geïnspireerd door thema's uit, bijvoorbeeld, aardrijkskunde, monetaire economie, econometrie, ontwikkeling of industriële organisatie.

column1: Het mastervak Internationale grondslagen van de indirecte belastingen begint met de behandeling van de internationaalrechtelijke context van het WTO-recht en de invloed daarvan op de heffing van indirecte belastingen en douanerechten in EU-verband. Vervolgens komt de werking van het EU-recht aan de orde (waaronder de verhouding primair en secundair recht) alsmede de doorwerking van het EU-recht in de nationale rechtsorde. Ten slotte wordt de plaats van de BTW binnen de interne markt van de EU behandeld, waarbij aandacht wordt besteed aan het ‘EC-Action Plan on VAT: towards a single EU VAT Area’.

column2: <title></title>

</style>

column1: <body>Na het volgen van dit vak is de student in staat om:

column2: • zelfstandig vraagstukken op het gebied van het internationale recht (WTO en WCO) en de invloed daarvan op indirecte belastingen en douane binnen het EU-recht te analyseren en op te lossen.
• de plaats van de indirecte belastingen en douanerechten binnen de EU interne markt te analyseren en te evalueren.
• complexe vraagstukken op het gebied van doorwerking van het EU-recht op de heffing van indirecte belastingen en het douanerecht te analyseren en op te lossen.

• de leerstukken van rechtstreekse werking van richtlijnen en rechtstreekse toepasselijkheid van verordeningen te onderscheiden, analyseren en evalueren en de rol van het HvJ EU bij de volle werking van het EU-recht te duiden.
• EU rechtsbeginselen toe te passen en te analyseren bij vraagstukken inzake indirecte belastingen en douanerecht.
• de structuur van de BTW-richtlijn en de wijze waarop deze bijdraagt aan de opheffing van de fiscale grenzen en het functioneren van de interne markt in de EU te onderkennen en te beschrijven.
• het ‘Action Plan on VAT: Towards a single EU VAT Area’ toe te passen en te analyseren in verhouding tot het huidige BTW-stelsel.

column1: Het mastervak Internationale grondslagen van de indirecte belastingen begint met de behandeling van de internationaalrechtelijke context van het WTO-recht en de invloed daarvan op de heffing van indirecte belastingen en douanerechten in EU-verband. Vervolgens komt de werking van het EU-recht aan de orde (waaronder de verhouding primair en secundair recht) alsmede de doorwerking van het EU-recht in de nationale rechtsorde. Ten slotte wordt de plaats van de BTW binnen de interne markt van de EU behandeld, waarbij aandacht wordt besteed aan het ‘EC-Action Plan on VAT: towards a single EU VAT Area’.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Na het volgen van dit vak is de student in staat om:

column2: • zelfstandig vraagstukken op het gebied van het internationale recht (WTO en WCO) en de invloed daarvan op indirecte belastingen en douane binnen het EU-recht te analyseren en op te lossen.
• de plaats van de indirecte belastingen en douanerechten binnen de EU interne markt te analyseren en te evalueren.
• complexe vraagstukken op het gebied van doorwerking van het EU-recht op de heffing van indirecte belastingen en het douanerecht te analyseren en op te lossen.

• de leerstukken van rechtstreekse werking van richtlijnen en rechtstreekse toepasselijkheid van verordeningen te onderscheiden, analyseren en evalueren en de rol van het HvJ EU bij de volle werking van het EU-recht te duiden.
• EU rechtsbeginselen toe te passen en te analyseren bij vraagstukken inzake indirecte belastingen en douanerecht.
• de structuur van de BTW-richtlijn en de wijze waarop deze bijdraagt aan de opheffing van de fiscale grenzen en het functioneren van de interne markt in de EU te onderkennen en te beschrijven.
• het ‘Action Plan on VAT: Towards a single EU VAT Area’ toe te passen en te analyseren in verhouding tot het huidige BTW-stelsel.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: In het mastervak Internationale handel komen op geïntegreerde wijze de douanerechtelijke, btw- en civielrechtelijke aspecten ten aanzien van deze aan globalisering onderhevige goederenstromen aan bod. Het vak bouwt daarmee voort op de vakken Internationale grondslagen van de indirecte belastingen en EU-douanerecht en accijnzen.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Na het volgen van dit vak is de student in staat om:

column2: • zelfstandig complexe vraagstukken vanuit btw- en douaneperspectief analyseren en oplossen op gebied van in- en uitvoer, intracommunautaire leveringen en de(her)structurering van complexe goederenstromen;
• de civielrechtelijke regelgeving met betrekking tot complexe internationale goederenstromen toe te passen op basis van de binnen dit vak verworven kennis en inzicht;
• de samenhang en de verschillen tussen de vaststelling van de douanewaarde enerzijds en verrekenprijzen anderzijds te analyseren;
• de samenloop tussen civielrechtelijke, btw- en douaneaspecten bij complexe internationale goederenstromen te onderkennen en te begrijpen.

column1: The third year of the MISOC bachelor starts with a ten week (block 1 and 2) elective. The elective enables students to broaden their knowledge by moving outside the boundaries of the MISOC programme, or, alternatively, specialize themselves further within the field of international social challenges. In this elective you can either 1) take a minor at the Erasmus University, 2) go on exchange to a partner university abroad or 3) do an internship. This course guide relates to the third option: internship.

This elective is intended for all MISOC bachelor students who are interested in enhance academic, career, and personal development. The goal is to gain experience in the (international) public sector. It is an opportunity to see how the theories learned during the bachelor are integrated into the practical world. The internship elective period will run from 3 September up to 9 November 2018. The internship should last at least 400 hours and is rewarded with 15 ECTS. You can only start earlier with the internship not prolong it, the internship must end by 9 November 2018. Starting the internship early is voluntary and does not increase the number of ECTS.
The internship guide with information about the internship (plan of action, report) can be found on the digital learning environment.

<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>At the end of the internship you will have:

column2: • Observed and participated in daily work activities and/or research within a (semi) public organization;
• Designed and conducted a small research project by using established techniques and insights of academic research;
• Applied academic knowledge and skills;
• Acquired insight into future career possibilities and personal preferences;
• Acquired international cultural knowledge.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In their second year, IBCoM students are required to take an internship in the field of communication and media. This internship can take place in a variety of fields, such as marketing, management, sales, corporate communications, public relations, internal communications, government, public affairs, education, journalism, the media and entertainment industries as well as the arts. This internship will enable students to train their communication and analytical skills and to apply their academic knowledge and skills in the professional world. Students are expected to work at a professional level, undertaking any tasks that are normally completed in the workplace of a company or organization. They should be practically oriented and be able to apply their academic insights and skills creatively and effectively in ""real world"" settings. On the internship pages on MyEur you can find the most relevant information about the internship and the internship manual.
Note: Students should have completed the course Communication and Media Labour Market Orientation (CM2008) before they may start with the internship (CM3041) in BA-2.

column1: Students have gained knowledge, understanding and awareness of:

column2: • Labor market prospects and (international) career opportunities for graduates in communication and media
• Practical applications of their academic knowledge and skills, while also acquiring additional knowledge and expanding and improving practical skills
• Expectations and requirements of (international) employers and internship providers in a variety of relevant fields

column1: Students have developed the skills and/or the mindset to:

column2: • Identify and reflect on their personal learning needs and interests (career goals and learning objectives)
• Orientate themselves on the (international) job and internship market, apply for an internship and develop an internship plan/report
• Work together with colleagues/clients from different cultural backgrounds and to critically reflect on their own intercultural competencies
• Grasp how a particular (international) company, organization or industry works and build professional networks in the field of their choice
• Testing a career interest and their own suitability for that career
